Mr. Speaker, I want to thank my colleague on the government side for her intervention in this debate.
She will have known that the recommendations of Justice Moshansky have created a bit of a stir in this House in terms of when they are going to be implemented by the government.
Justice Moshansky pointed out that there was an anomaly between the regulating of the pilots and the engineers and the cabin crew, the flight attendants. The pilots are regulated. There are regulations, as safety measures, that specify how many hours they can work.
This House, through the Standing Committee on Transport, in a review of the Aeronautics Act, gave the government the power to regulate hours of work for flight attendants, the motion that I made supported by the Official Opposition and, most important, by the government.
Justice Moshansky, not knowing that we had done that when he wrote his report, said we should do it. We are actually ahead of the game. The government in its response tabled by the Minister of Transport did not say it is going to do it. It said it was going to refer it to the Dryden commission implementation project. The government response says: "Concur action on the way, a new amendment to the Aeronautics Act enacted March 19, 1992 provides enabling authority for making a regulation respecting flight time limitations for flight attendants. The application of a new regulatory proposal will be referred to the Diyden commission implementation project".
My question to the member is why did the government choose this method when normally it would pull together an ad hoc committee representing the industry, the union, which in this case is the Canadian Union of Public Employees, and the department to draft the regulations that are workable? Instead, it has sent it off to this implementation project which has a whole range of things to do.
Is this the government's way of deep-sixing this very logical change in legislation as opposed to acting on it immediately so that flight attendants can have the same kind of protection the pilots do?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
I thank my colleague for the question. He has raised a very good point. There were a lot of excellent recommendations that came out in Justice Moshansky's report and I believe our government has acted on 49 per cent. We have taken specific action on 49 per cent of the recommendations. We are committed, absolutely and openly, to responding to and acting upon the 191 recommendations.
I believe that you were speaking specifically to the regulating of pilots and cabin crew, the flight crew attendants. The pilots' area has been addressed concerning the number of hours of work. It has to be addressed.
The Minister of Transport has set into place an implementation team that will be looking at the specific areas. There will be no duplication of services required. We have exactly the same goal. I agree with you that safety has to come first.
As I mentioned in my speech, never ever have we tampered with the safety rules. I really welcome the member's specific questions dealing with the hours of work of the flight crews. They have to be limited. You will find that the minister, through his implementation team, will come up with the same goal. I quite agree with you.
It is interesting how prior to the Moshansky report the government acted upon a lot of the recommendations. I can honestly say, and you will have to agree, that we did not sit back and wait and wait. We knew there were errors that we could respond to, or that the Department of Transport could respond to, in order to improve safety. You will find that we have exactly the same goal and the minister has in place an implementation team and we already have responded to 49 per cent and will complete the rest.

Mr. Speaker, there are two ways of looking at this debate in terms of whether the government was correct.

speechtext: I would appreciate it if you would indicate if your party is going to split the time between speakers in this debate.

I am happy to so indicate.
There are two approaches that can be used in this issue and that is whether to deregulate at all and how deregulation took place in Canada as a result of this government's policies.
First of all, most Canadians see deregulation in the context of deregulation, privatization, the free trade agreement and the destruction of a lot in this country which has been constructive over the years and the recognition of the unique characteristics of this country.
Deregulation is very much like the free trade agreement in that in principle it was fine but when looked at in terms of the fine print, it did not recognize significant differences that existed and exist now in Canada as compared to the United States. There are a lot of differences that are inherent in our country such as the large distances, the thin population, increased energy costs and characteristics and considerations of that sort which have burdened the free trade agreement as well as the question of deregulation.
April 2, 1992

I want to deal with the question of deregulation primarily by looking upon its manifestations in Windsor and to point out in how many different ways the government seemed not to know what were the consequences when it got into this. Had the government committed itself to deregulation then it should have put in place programs, structures and policies which would have been able to somewhat mitigate the inevitable implications of the implementation of deregulation.
Unfortunately we got an indication of the depth and the complexity of thinking by this government when we heard the speech by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport. I remember two things he said quite sharply. He said that if you have one plane in the air you will get so many accidents and if you have two planes in the air you are going to get more accidents. That shows you the depth of analysis that was conferred upon this debate and reflects the depth of analysis that was involved when this government chose to deregulate on the basis of relieving the economic burden on the transportation industry.
In the name of competition.

What this is supposed to mean I do not know in the context of saying that it has nothing to do with safety because obviously the measures involved in safety do confer a substantial economic burden both on the government and the carriers.
Windsor is a strategic point in Canada. It is the nexus of air, ground and rail transportation between Canada and the United States insofar as Ontario is concerned. If we look at each of the areas, trucking, air transport and railways, we are going to find examples of the impact of what this government did with respect to deregulation clearly manifest.
With respect to trucking, what we have found is that in 1989 there were 57 bankruptcies in Ontario of truckers. In 1990 there were 140 or so, and in 1991 there were 157. Each year after deregulation the number of truckers in Ontario going bankrupt increased. In Windsor, day after day, one reads of truckers going under.
I see behind me the former transport critic. He pointed out at the time of the debate, as so many others have pointed out, that the larger costs, the larger tax

rates, the lower depreciation and all of those things, plus the habits on the American side of longer runs, longer days and bigger companies with lower marginal costs, without some help for trucking, would inevitably lead to its destruction if it is, at the same time, paired with the freedom of American truckers to come over and carry loads in Canada from one place to the other and not just between Canada and the United States.
The consequence of this government's deregulatory policy was essentially the destruction of the trucking industry in Windsor. The minister says: "The government has taken certain measures to help the trucking industry". What he should have said is: "The government took certain measures to relieve what is left of the trucking industry".
Windsor understands deregulation. We had the Ambassador Bridge blocked twice by angry truckers. We saw highway 401 outside of Toronto blocked by angry truckers. We saw right here on the Hill hundreds of truckers making their point known. It was only then that the government began to act to correct what could have been corrected, what could have been anticipated when it introduced its policy of deregulation.
With respect to railways-and I do not want to take too long with this-but we heard about VIA Rail having to take all of its cars on the Quebec-Windsor corridor off the tracks because of a mechanical difficulty. Mechanical difficulties seem to be showing up so frequently in all of those areas.
Even more important than the frequent discovery of mechanical difficulties on VIA Rail and the other railway carriers in our neighbourhood-and that is not by the way just Canadian carriers-what we see is an utter disregard for the mechanical problems that American inspected cars exhibit when they come into Canada which are unattended by the Canadian transport inspection system.
Deregulation is not just about safety considerations, it is about economic considerations. We have a situation now in Windsor where we have a railway tunnel that goes from Detroit to Windsor that both CN and CP use.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the question of my hon colleague.

As I said, our present transportation critic and many intelligent, insightful people on the government side as well as within the Liberal Party were able to anticipate the obvious. Even in the absence of that, the very burden of increased flights really indicated the need for more regulatory resources. Many of those regulatory resources are supplied by Transport Canada.
At Pearson, there were two things that any idiot who did not know anything would have known. Mr. Speaker, I welcome the opportunity to support my colleague from Thunder Bay who has put forward the motion:
That this House condemns the government for its unwillingness to concede that the deregulation of the Canadian transport industry has been a failure and in fact has led to fewer carriers, fewer jobs, higher prices, reduced service and less safe operations in air, road and rail transportation.
I want to direct my remarks to the railway industry, but I want to also address the answer given by the member for Calgary South. In my riding which is very close to the Calgary South riding of the member, part of the highway from Field to Golden on the number one Trans-Canada Highway could be best described as a cow trail rather than a highway.
Where the federal government used to have control of transportation and the trucking transportation, they have allowed the provinces to reach agreements that are much less stringent. Highway tests were taken at Golden

by the RCMP and many trucks had to be taken off the highway because they did not meet the standards. Large trucks carrying mobile homes or modular homes that are 30 and 40 feet in length used to have pilot trucks driving in front of them to ensure safety on the highway. Down through these heavily graded roads, through these sharp curves, they are now travelling without pilots.
I want to say to the member that it is not safe and there are going to be more and more bad accidents. Had this deregulation not taken place, I am almost certain we would never have had that serious accident in Vancouver in which an innocent family was sitting down at the waterfront in its car waiting for the ferry and that truck broke loose with hot tar and came down and smashed on top of those people. What kind of safety did those people have? That must come directly to the deregulation of the trucking industry and this government has to take full responsibility for that.
I want to refer most of my remarks to the railway industry because I was a railway car inspector for CP Rail for 19 years, from the early 40s into the 60s. In those days, out of the blue would come a government CTC man who would stop a train in the yard and inspect and not allow the cars to go from that terminal. Consequently they had to be switched out and nothing could be done.
Those kinds of safety precautions were important. We had car inspectors right across the country inspecting those trains. Every so often there was a spot check made and the safety was ensured and the government knew exactly what the conditions of those trains were.
Through deregulation that has all gone by the board now. Through deregulation the railway industry has been allowed to reduce the crews on those trains. It is hauling twice as much tonnage. The industry has been allowed to take the caboose off the trains. It has been allowed to put an electric marker on the tail end of the trains and made strong commitments toward it. Now it is reaching the point at which it is talking about putting reflectors on the ends of the trains. Can you imagine the safety of the trains with a reflector on the back and the curves on these railways and not being able to see that reflector until a headlight actually hits it?

There are signals and so on throughout the country showing where the occupancies are, but just the same, surely to goodness we have not reached a point at which we have a 100-car train standing on a piece of track in trouble, with a reflector on the tail end telling the next crew that the train is stopped. That is not safety.
I say to this House that we had better get back to regulating these kinds of things because if we do not, we are going to have some very serious accidents.
The industry also made commitments that car inspectors would be maintained at these points. It said that Cranbrook in my riding would be designated as a car inspection point. Last year, the railway cut back on the car inspections at that point. There are cars coming in from the United States on interchange. They are coming into our yards, not to the first terminal, the first point where it used to be when they entered Canada for an inspection, but coming on into the city of Cranbrook, into its yard where it has now a reduced car inspection group and it does not even know how safe those cars are.
I have reports showing that there has been leakage of chemicals in that yard. The response team that is supposed to be set up by the deregulation is not carrying out the provisions of what the regulations even call for. That response team, if it is going to be a response team to deal with the tragedy, must meet on a regular basis with the firefighters in those communities, with the ambulances in those communities and with the railway companies. If it does not do that on a regular basis, then it is not worth the paper it is written on.
That is the kind of thing that has taken place because of deregulation. I do not blame my union friends on the railway for negotiating because when they are negotiating to reduce a crew or reduce a system, the company offers them large buy-outs, large settlements.
It is not unfamiliar and not unethical for that trade union to want to support its members and try to get the best deal it can. It realizes that it is not going to be protected by governments. Safety regulations are not going to be protected by governments. If it is going to happen anyhow, it might as well get the best settlements it can. Naturally it negotiates for buy-outs and those kinds of things. That is not running a safe, efficient railway and that is causing the kinds of problems that we are having right across Canada.
The riding that I represent, Kootenay East, has probably one of the highest grades. The trains carry 10,000 to 14,000 tonnes a piece. They come down those grades and the hill from a glacier. After, they come through the
Connaught Tunnel or the new MacDonald Thnnel and into Revelstoke. It is all heavy grades, heavy tonnage. There are no cabooses on the back ends. All of the crews are in the head ends of the trains when they hit Revelstoke. There are one or two car inspectors. There used to be as many as 25 or 30.
That is not safety. The air brakes used to be cleaned every four years. The air brakes used to have to be tagged, back ordered and sent to the repair track and new ones put on. Now it is unlimited. They travel across this country with the dust from the coal, the dust from the road bed going into those air brakes that are required to be clean and efficient at all times, carrying hundreds and thousands of tonnes. We have reached the point at which there is not even a mandatory cleaning date.
It used to be four years. Four years is a long time. It used to be four years and it had to be updated. It used to be 90 days for a test. The brakes would have to be tested to make sure the air did not leak and that the brakes were working properly. None of that is in existence any more.
That is what deregulation has done to the railway system. It is not safe and we are going to have more and more serious railway accidents across the country.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to congratulate the member for a fine speech and an analysis of the situation. There are probably very few people in the House who have the expertise he has. He was an on-line worker with the railroad. I grant you that the member for Regina-Lums-den was as well, but it was a different kind of line, the telegraph line.
The point is (hat over the years there has been a body of regulation built up which this government is in the process of destroying.
I would like to ask the member why on earth were these regulations put in place in the first place?

I would like to thank the member for the question. He goes back exactly to the situation. We have a transcontinental railway system going east and west. Many railway cars would come in and tie on to us through the prairies and so on, coming in from the United States. Many of the grain shipments and car branch lines would be coming in. Therefore, the government of the day decided it could not allow a railway system to travel across Canada tagging on all of these cars that are coming in from other areas and so on without an efficient inspection.
April 2, 1992

The government could not trust the companies to do it, and rightfully so. After all, they are in it for profit.
There was a very efficient and a very wonderful Canadian railway transport inspection group. It was respected by all railway employees. When it came to town, the engineer set the brake and he would not move that train. When that guy came to town, he had the authority to stop that train. Nobody was to touch it. He would walk down that train and there was no funny business. At the end of the day, it was all marked by CTC and it stated that this car was in order. It took as many as 33 per cent of the cars off of those trains for defective hand-brakes, defective grab irons. It would make them go to the repair track. They were all marked and recorded. With that kind of an inspection by the government, it found the defaults even with all that system in place. Imagine what is going on out there today with the railway system.
Mr. Speaker, I just want to ask my hon. friend whether it is true about the reduction of railway car inspectors both by the railroads and the CTC.

Mr. Speaker, I will be very brief. Yes it is true and the unfortunate part of it is that in the days of these government inspectors, they were highly qualified people.
The car inspector had to serve an apprenticeship of four years in order to be qualified to do that inspection. Now we have lost that because there are fewer and fewer inspectors. There are fewer apprenticeships taking place and the railway industry is going to be in one serious situation if this government does not change its views with regard to deregulation.
Supply
failure. It has not worked and is basically paramount and equated with a government that does not have any answers or any policy program or framework with which to guide, nurture and shape not only the transportation infrastructure, but a very integral part of Canada's economic livelihood. Another aspect of the unity debate in the last couple of months and in the future months is the structure and the transportation role that the government has played in keeping Canadians linked with one another and keeping this large country from east, west and north united.
The government started talking about deregulation in 1985. Finally a few years later, through legislation, it realized that unfortunate nightmare. It preferred to allow the marketplace to dictate. It preferred to take a hands off attitude and allow the transportation policy and network go its own natural course. When we talk today on the floor of the House of Commons about its failure, we can define that failure according to a number of different factors.
The first one is that this government promised my former colleague in the transport critic portfolio, the member for Humber-St. Barbe-Baie Verte, and other members of the caucus that deregulation would lead to great competition, increased competition in the marketplace. It would see the start of regional airlines right across this nation. What happened under deregulation? The reality now is that we are into a duopoly that may soon find itself a monopoly by one airline alone.
We have gone from regional carriers that existed before this government came in to a situation that is largely dominated by almost 95 per cent of all air movement.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to participate in the opposition day motion today which essentially tells the obvious tale.
The obvious tale in terms of the government's transportation policy is exactly that deregulation has been a
I am going to concentrate on the air industry because my friend talked about the rail industry. We have gone from an industry that was beginning to become more versatile to an industry that is dominated and controlled 95 per cent by Air Canada and Canadian Airlines.

April 2, 1992
Supply
I have nothing against Air Canada and Canadian, but one of the commitments by this government was to further diversify the industry and give opportunities to the smaller regional air carriers to flourish and it has not. Exactly the reverse has taken place.
City Express used to operate in my area of Toronto and shuttle to different parts of Canada and the United States. City Express, started by Vic Papalardo, is no longer there. One of the reasons he is not there, not the only reason but one of the contributing reasons is that Air Canada squeezed him out of the market. Air Ontario, through economies of scale offered reductions that unfortunately City Express was not able to match over the long-term. So he kept extending himself and extending himself. Then the world collapsed around him. As City Express goes, so do other regional air carriers.
On the measuring yardstick of further competition, the failure is quite clear and obvious.
The government also talked about further competition creating more jobs. Well, with regional carriers going out of business and with Nationair, Air Canada and Canadian, we have had over 5,000 Canadians lose their jobs in the last 16 to 18 months just in the airline industry alone.
Where is the infusion of jobs because of this ideology to free enterprise, no government regulation apparatus, the opportunity to try to guide and make the marketplace fair?
The government also talked on this third promise that it was going to bring greater quality of service to the regions of the country. I question that because it can talk about the odd extra flight into one community or another.
But we should also list a number of the communities in northern Ontario, for example, Sudbury and Sault Ste. Marie. Look at Atlantic Canada after the government gutted VIA Rail, after it cannot build proper highways with federal support. It also began to take jet service out of Atlantic Canada, northern Ontario and parts of the west.
Canadians are beginning to ask themselves what standard is at play here. If you happen to live in Vancouver or Montreal, or Toronto where we have the flagship airport into the major Canadian markets, there is frequency of service and quality of service in terms of jets. If you happen to live in Sudbury or Sault Ste. Marie, all of a
sudden Air Canada pulls out its jets. If you want to go into Deer Lake you have to go by prop. Why?
We are discussing the very tender and fragile nature of national unity. Transportation tears at that fragile quilt because Canadians are seeing different treatment depending on where one lives in this country. Add cost recovery services on top of that. Atlantic Canadian airports are paying more proportionally than users are at Pearson airport which happens to be the flagship airport of our country.
Those Canadians living in those regions are asking themselves: Where is the Messiah that was supposed to be deregulation in terms of quality of service? On that note again it gets a failing grade.
We then enter open skies. Can you imagine if we get into cabotage and open skies? American carriers will be allowed to come into Canada. Do you think for one moment that American mega air carriers are going to give a darn about Deer Lake, about Moose Jaw, about Sault Ste. Marie, Sarnia or Sudbury? They are interested in the major hubs of the Canadian air market. That is where their bottom line is.
If the situation is bad now, what is it going to be like if this government does not draw its line in the sand, does not articulate the bottom line in a free trade arrangement in the skies?
We have already seen their bottom line with the free trade agreement. Never mind correcting that. Now they want to get into an agreement with the Mexicans and the Americans on North American free trade.
Where are we going to be in terms of quality of service if we allow American carriers the option of going wherever they wish in this country? We know what is going to happen. It is going to gravitate in the worst shape around those mega major hubs and again further exacerbate the gulf that Canadians are feeling economically now, depending on where one lives in this country.
Lastly, on this side of the House there have been quotes and quotes of my successive transport critics who have obtained assurances and guarantees from the Deputy Prime Minister down to the litany of hall of famers who have been transport ministers. They have a rotating door over there for the transport ministers. Each of them swore that safety was not only going to be protected but also enhanced.
April 2, 1992

Yet, what is the reality of the safety variable? Despite the government's deregulation talk in 1985, the industry started planning deregulation before it even happened. Rather than predicting greater volumes of traffic, greater air movements, greater passenger volumes and rather than plan safety mechanisms for that increased travel, we have had a reduction.
There are fewer air traffic controllers today than there were before deregulation started. There were 1,800 air traffic controllers in Canada prior to deregulation. We are now at 1,400.
In 1985 when the government started talking deregulation, it froze the number of air traffic controllers that were able to come but of the school in Cornwall. Rather than plan in anticipation of greater need, it froze the number. Why? Because it has this thing called ideology and it cannot move beyond that ideological framework.
Now the Minister of Transport is forced to scramble to push through more controllers in Cornwall. Justice Moshansky suggested in his report that we were short 400 to at least have basic minimum standards.
Do you know how many commercial aircraft inspectors we have today? We have 31 commercial aircraft inspectors. In 1988 there was a leaked confidential departmental memo that said for the period leading to 1988 at least 41 commercial aircraft inspectors were needed.
Now we are at 1992 and we are still 10 below the threshold that was established in 1988. And this government has the audacity and the temerity, which is a favourite word of the Prime Minister, to say that it kept pace with its safety regulation and safety apparatus.
In terms of open skies, if we are going to have greater American involvement in our skies I think it is quite well known that our safety apparatus is much safer than that of the Americans. What implications does that have for transporting Canadians? Are we harmonizing-another favourite word of the Prime Minister-positively their system to ours on a safety basis and not the reverse? I do not hear too much discussion by the minister on that when we talk about airline deregulation or an open skies arrangement between the two countries.
Justice Moshansky said it very brutally, clearly and frankly. I am paraphrasing, but he essentially said that
Supply
the combination of a deregulated regime in the air and fiscal restraint has undermined the safety variable in the delicate equation that is air travel. That is essentially what he said, that fiscal policy and deregulation, the combination thereof, as our critic said was a collision in mid-air. And the victim was safety.
Now, we do not want to be alarmists. We do not want to scare passengers. I still believe that the infrastructure has survived this government to the degree that there is a basic foundation.
The premise of our arguments is that if there is going to be deregulation, if volume is going to be increased, if fleets are going to be making more movements-and they are aging fleets-then it is logical that the safety net of the deregulation must keep up with the times. But it is being reduced because of that fiscal ideology.
It is the same thing in the city of Toronto. The Minister of National Defence said: "On the basis of fiscal restraint, we need to consolidate the military depots from Moncton and Downsview and Montreal". Fair enough. So the government commissioned a study in 1990 to obtain the recommendation of which place should have the consolidation.
The report in 1990 by the productivity group gave four recommendations. The first recommendation on the most cost-effective consolidation was Kingston. It was suggested that based on defence criteria and cost, Kingston, along the Toronto-Montreal access, was the logical place to consolidate. The last, least suitable, least economically viable location in the entire Toronto-King-ston-Montreal access was Montreal. Where did the minister consolidate? In Montreal.
I do not want to pit region against region, or city against city. And I do not want to bring Toronto up at the economic cost or price of Montreal, because the shape of the economy in Montreal is equal or worse than it is in Toronto.
At the same time, I do not believe that those 300 Canadians in Toronto should be treated in this fashion. Three hundred job losses in Toronto, very definite, very concrete, very real. I have met with workers already and I have met with the union. I have received their letters, and they cannot understand the rationale of the government moving in this way.

April 2, 1992
Supply
As a Toronto member of Parliament, I would like a few answers from the government, if in fact fiscal restraint is one of its more important ideological compasses that guides its government activities. Because even if it was to be Kingston, then at least it would be seen to be fair. Canadians in Montreal or Canadians in Toronto would then be allowed to perhaps minimize the pain of moving their families and relocating to a new community.
I could sell that in Toronto. I am sure my friends in Quebec could also sell that to Montrealers. But what I cannot sell in Toronto is when people are puzzled legitimately about the rationale of this decision.
People clearly conclude that it has nothing to do with consolidation, nothing to do with financial savings. It has everything to do with the political mind set of this Minister of National Defence who fuels long enough in Canada to give us these crazy decisions, then jets off and we have to clean up the mess.
The other negative aspect of that is that the minister who hails from Quebec, a fellow Canadian from Quebec who is engaged in this national unity debate, by that very decision triggers anti-Montreal, anti-Quebec sentiments. Workers said things about our fellow Canadians that ought not to be said of. The minister has to learn that when he makes a decision that becomes nearly indefensible, he is contributing to the forces that he himself, and fellow Canadians in Quebec are trying to address, together with all Canadians.
What we have is an economic military decision that finds itself in the international unity mix. That is very, very dangerous. With respect to the case of the military depot, I wrote to the minister yesterday and asked that he and his officials reconsider. I am not even asking them to keep the Downsview base in Toronto at present levels.
If that is his decision, I will applaud that decision. If he at least can tell Canadians it is the most effective and cost-efficient and in the best interests of our national security, if those three variables happen to be found in Kingston, then this member of Parliament will defend the Kingston alternative. Otherwise this member of Parliament will be hard pressed to explain and give a rationale to workers who will be coming to my office
tomorrow and Saturday, and saying: "Okay, there is a net loss of 300 jobs. Now what do I do?"
We know what the recession has done. We know what the free trade agreement has done to Toronto. We know that there was not any job stimulus. At least allow this government to maintain a current level of employment without a government action that says: "You will be the net losers of 300 without any replacement".
How am I supposed to keep 300 families believing in Canada under that perspective? It is the same thing when we talk about safety. It wants to deregulate, it is the government. It wants to increase the number of flights, it is the government. But it also has the responsibility to provide a safety apparatus that keeps up with the pace of deregulation and that does not fall behind and becomes victim to an ideological government that simply is looking not to the future but to the past.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Reid (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I know my colleague will comment on the last part of the member's comments. I have some sympathy for what my friend across the way has said about air travel. As you know, a number of us spend a lot of time on aeroplanes. I am getting frustrated.
In the old days when you flew out of St. John's you would have to phone to find out if the plane was going or not. In the last six years flying in and out of St. John's, I have only been taken out of that airport once by weather. Now, you just go.
When you arrive at St. John's at six o'clock in the morning, you cannot tell if the planes are going or not because there are so many bloody aircraft flying. You do not know what is going on. There are two Canadian Pacific 737s sitting there every single morning. There are two Air Canada jets. There is a 727 and now they are bringing in the Airbus, plus all the DASH-8s that are lined up along the tarmac. I agree with him. You do not know what is going on, there are so many aeroplanes flying.
Here we are, 560,000 people down there. That is the size of North York. We are sitting there. What do we have? Out of St. John's every day, there are 13 flights to Halifax. Ten of those are direct. Out of St. John's every day, there are nine flights to Gander. Out of St. John's every single day during the week, there are eight flights to Deer Lake.
April 2, 1992

This is unheard of and unprecedented. The situation in Deer Lake is quite serious. There are seven flights a day from Deer Lake to Halifax and six of those are direct. The situation is serious in Deer Lake. Deregulation has allowed so much increase in aircraft that it has blown the government expenditure. We had to build a brand new airport in Deer Lake, Tobin Memorial Airport. There it is, all walls and no roof. The head is right off it.
This is what deregulation has done. With all the 737s and the 727s and the Airbuses and the 146 flying around, including jet service from Stephenville to Halifax and Montreal, how can my friend across the way from Toronto explain this in light of deregulation when we have an unprecedented amount of aircraft, flights and seats and deregulation has supposedly closed us down?

Mr. Speaker, I am glad my hon. friend along the way got up because he was not listening to the words I was trying to convey to the House and to Canadians.
I did not define Ontario as being only Toronto and he should not define Newfoundland as only revolving around St. John's. We can ask him about Goose Bay. What about Deer Lake? What about Gander? What about Stephenville? Newfoundland is bigger than St. John's, as Ontario is bigger than Toronto. That is why I tried to articulate, as a Toronto member, the needs of fellow Canadians in Sudbury, in Sault Ste. Marie, in Hamilton and elsewhere across the country.
It was also interesting that the member did not touch upon the whole financial, ideological bent of this government as I defined through the military depot. Perhaps one of the reasons was that between the gentleman's riding and the riding of the minister of fisheries from St. John's West, they essentially have 82 per cent of the small craft budget when both those ridings have the smallest percentages of the fisheries industry. Maybe that is why the member did not touch upon why the military depot, when it was recommended to go to Kingston for financial and other variables went to Montreal. That is exactly the malaise that this government has gripped itself with and it is a malaise that, unlike the government polling or strategist, a malaise
Supply
that is very well understood and recognized by Canadians who will do something about that very quickly.

Mr. Speaker, I will make it short so hopefully my other colleague can get in. Just on the same line, I want to ask my colleague from York North whether he recognizes that a lot of those flights referred to by the member from across the way are two airlines leaving at the same time going to the same destination. We certainly see in Ontario where Air Canada flies at nine o'clock and Canadian flies at 9.05 from Toronto to Ottawa or to Thunder Bay or Montreal or wherever. There is a lot of duplication, unnecessary duplication, and I suspect it is the same thing in Atlantic Canada. I have been at those airports where there are a lot of planes on the ground first thing in the morning, but by nine o'clock they are all gone. You do not see them again until four o'clock because everybody is sort of stacked up.
I wonder if the member could respond to that analysis.

Mr. Speaker, the member, and I thank him, alluded to a fact that I failed to mention. Another promise of deregulation was that it was going to benefit the consumer in terms of the ticket price. This Deputy Prime Minister was the first to lead off by saying Canadian consumers, the travelling Canadian public, will experience reductions in air fare. With the only exception of advance booking months before, the average cost of a seat on any aircraft has not only increased, but increased at a greater pace than the cost of inflation.
That is another failure point. The member speaks generically to something that I would favour as an individual member on this side. We do have two very competent transport critics who are articulating the transport view on behalf of the leader and the Liberal Party of Canada. We need some form of government role, not to create greater bureaucracies, but to fill a very important vacuum that has been created by deregulation.
I believe that Canadians and the nature of our country require some form of re-regulation because re-regulation, or a form thereof, is one answer to the whole plight facing both Ar Canada and Canadian.

Supply
If the aircraft industry in this country and the government can sit down I know that we can find a way in which both those airlines can live well and can compete well. We need a form of reregulation that, whether domestically or internationally, begins to address the situation logically and carves out that air space, rather than allowing this vacuum to make Air Canada and Canadian go at each other with the ultimate situation being the vulnerability of both airlines to the detriment of the interests of the Canadian travelling public and the Canadian economy in general.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to take part in this debate on an opposition motion.
This Tuesday, the federal Minister of Transport made public the final report of the Commission of Inquiry into the Air Ontario Crash at Dryden. This inquiry dealt first and foremost with a human tragedy. I fully sympathize with the survivors and the families of the victims of this crash.
At the same time, Mr. Corbeil reassured all Canadians that Canada's air transport system is safe. According to the Canadian Transportation Safety Board, the statistics on aircraft registered in Canada clearly show that in the last decade there was a marked improvement in aviation safety in Canada. In fact, from 1981 to 1991, the accident rate for aircraft registered in Canada dropped by 35 per cent. The minister added: "I promise to see this improvement continue".
During the whole three-year period of this investigation, seventeen recommendations were made, but while the inquiry was going on, the department implemented some other measures to improve aviation safety.
I speak today as the member of the House of Commons who represents the largest riding of all 10 provinces, not counting the two northern territories. The riding covers over half a million square kilometres and has more than 20 airports, some belonging to the Inuit sector, some to the Cree sector and commercial and other airports belonging to the Government of Canada.
Concerning the March 10 accident in Ontario, I have a newspaper article here from December 28, 1989 by
Sylvain Blanchard. We can rely on it, because journalists provide us with excellent reports. The headline is: "Air deregulation in Canada: very few bargains, but improved service". The article says: "The changes were much less painful than in the United States. In 1985, when the deregulation of air transport began in Canada, the carriers acted like a group of savages at a feast. Some, like Wardair, that shouted on the rooftops that they would take over one third of the market, had indigestion".
The image is striking, but Robert Obadia, founding president of Nationair, paints a positive picture of air transport deregulation in this country. He thinks that Canada's experience was much less painful than the experience our southern neighbours had, where air transport has been deregulated since 1978. "Deregulation in Canada had hardly any impact on ticket prices," he hastened to add. "They continue to rise at the rate of inflation and the bargains one finds here and there are largely explained by efficient seat management. However, deregulation has considerably improved service in small communities."
Speaking of small communities, let us consider northern Abitibi and Air Creebec. At hearings on air service in remote and northern regions, Chief Billy Diamond, the founding president, was asking whether it was adequate. He said: "The Crees founded Air Creebec to provide air transportation along the coast of Hudson Bay and James Bay and inland. The company, which is run by aboriginal people, provides a reliable and efficient service which is constantly expanding".
And I could go on. Air Creebec strongly supports Transport Canada's new air transportation policy. As for the smaller communities in the north, in the Inuit settlements, Air Inuit, which carries quite a few passengers, says that the local landing strips were in veiy bad shape for many years. After considerable pressure, the federal and provincial governments have agreed to fund construction operations that should bring all airstrips up to standard by 1990.
My point is that both governments, the province of Quebec and the federal government, have invested more than $100 million under the James Bay Agreement-

Every year Canadians across this country look forward to the month of April as their favourite hockey teams take to the ice to do battle in the National Hockey League playoffs.
To many Canadians, hockey is more than just a game. It is part of our culture, part of our identity and a source of pride to us all. Hockey is indeed our national sport.
Hockey is also a business. Last night the business aspect of the game took precedence over the interest of hockey fans. As the players and owners failed in negotiating an agreement, a strike has now interrupted the hockey season.
While the players may lose pay and the owners may lose revenue, the big losers will be the loyal legions of Canadian hockey fans who year in and year out look forward to watching the Stanley Cup playoffs.
Players and owners owe it to all Canadians to make every possible effort to reach an agreement and get back out on the ice.

Mr. Speaker, tragedy struck my riding last night. Barn No. 3 at Mohawk Raceway was destroyed by fire.
Dead this morning are 79 of Canada's finest racing horses, still lying in their stalls. Only 11 standardbreds
were saved and that was due to the efforts of one heroic, and as yet unnamed trainer, who tried to battle the blaze himself before being defeated by it.
Among the lost lives is Scooter's Boy, a three year old colt which many believe had the potential to become a Canadian champion.
I want to express my dismay and sympathy for all those who raised, trained and loved these creatures. The loss is enormous to this industry, which is the largest in my riding. Of course, it is not just an economic loss. Destroyed were 79 athletes, animals of beauty and courage, which will be missed by all who knew them and cheered them on.

Mr. Speaker, a delegation of five New Democrat MPs has just returned from Washington, D.C. where we met with key players in the Canada-U.S. softwood lumber dispute.
In our discussions, it became alarmingly clear that the political agenda behind the U.S. actions is really all about free trade in raw logs. The Americans want access to Canada's timber resources and are using the countervail to beat us into submission.
The U.S. lumber lobby claims that if Canada would only lift its ban on raw log export, the U.S. countervail would dissolve. Representatives for U.S. Senators Pack-wood and Baucus stated flatly that access to Canada's raw log market is "the prize". They see Canadian timber as a resource to be exploited.
This is an issue of sovereignty. As Canadians, control of our resources is vital to the control of our economy. Canada's provincial and federal governments must stand resolute and say "no" to this invasive U.S. action.

Mr. Speaker, the potential plague facing our western agriculture, forestry and shipping industries is of grave concern to all of us. The Asian gypsy moth must not be allowed to spread. To ensure that it does not, quick and decisive action must be taken.

April 2, 1992
Agriculture Canada will spray next week to eliminate the threat. The agent that will be used in the spraying is Foray 48B which contains a bacteria that is eaten by the gypsy caterpillar, which kills it before it can take on its destructive moth form.
This is a naturally occurring bacteria that is not harmful to humans. The parties that have been involved in developing the Asian gypsy moth eradication program and verifying its safety include Agriculture Canada, B.C. Plant Protection Advisory Council, Forestry Canada, B.C. Ministry of Forestry, the Ministry of Health, federal Department of National Health and Welfare, and the Chief Medical Officer for Vancouver.
This agent has been used numerous times before in British Columbia as well as in the U.S. without ill effects. There is no evidence to suggest that this case will be any different. Some have attempted to suggest that this spraying will be a hazard to the people and the environment of Vancouver. However, this is not true and should be considered inexcusable fearmongering.

Mr. Speaker, if the government is planning to pursue its urban renewal program in Winnipeg's older neighbourhoods, which would also create the jobs Manitoba so badly needs, I would suggest that before announcing its plans, the government first provide guarantees that local people, including the business community, and also those in St. Boniface and St-Vital, will be involved in the project.

I would also ask the government whether or not it has any other plan for cities such as Winnipeg and many others in Canada, to try to create employment for those Canadians who want to work.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Department of Veterans Affairs is to be commended
for the ad that was produced to mark the 75th anniversary of the battle of Vimy Ridge.
Veterans in my riding have often complained about the way Canadian history is taught in our schools. They say young people know more about American victories than our own.
That is why it is good to see the story of one of the greatest victories in our history. Seventy-five years ago this week, the Canadian Corps achieved what other armies before it had failed to do and showed the whole world what a young country like Canada was able to accomplish.
Mr. Speaker, I am delighted to hear that Canadians will also have a chance to learn more about the Dieppe raid. Fifty years ago this year, Canadians were chosen to test the defences of Hitler's continental fortress, and like the Canadian Corps at Vimy, our forces responded with a great deal of courage and discipline. These campaigns taught us a lasting lesson. As it says in the ad about the victory at Vimy, courage and solidarity triumphed.

Mr. Speaker, Gallup is giving pollsters a bad name as a result of political bias and really stupid questions.
Take today's question: "Should a social charter be placed in the Constitution to ensure national standards for social programs, or should each provincial government decide how to implement social programs in a province?"
What is a social charter intended to do? It is intended to produce the national standards for social programs, which, in general, will be implemented by a provincial government within a province, like medicare and social assistance.
I know what tomorrow's Gallup question will be. "Should one clean one's teeth with a toothbrush or with toothpaste?" Anticipated response: "Eighty per cent of Canadians agree that Gallup should be cleaned up; 20 per cent think Gallup is a horse". That is judging strictly on scientific merit.
April 2, 1992

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as you know, Canadians everywhere next week will pay tribute to the memory of those in the Canadian Corps who 75 years ago achieved what so many before them had failed to do in the successful assault on Vimy Ridge.
This victory at Vimy Ridge marks, in the opinion of many historians, the real birth of Canada as a nation, whose lingering colonial status was finally put behind it. This most famous victory was a tribute both to the bravery and the intelligence of those who participated. Canadian officers, most of whom were citizen soldiers, had no stubborn attachment to the military tactics of previous battles. In fact, their willingness to be innovative and to adopt new tactics was a key to their success. Moreover, every member of the Canadian Corps was given a role and an explanation. Each in reality was a vital part of the process.
We know what Vimy meant to Canadians 75 years ago. It also could mean much to our future if we follow the lead of that pioneering generation who, in looking up at Vimy Ridge, refused to be overwhelmed by the obstacles which faced them. They chose instead to see an opportunity to be realized.
Mr. Speaker, may we have the self-discipline required to follow in their footsteps.

Mr. Speaker, ACOA has recently published The State of Small Business and Entrepreneurship in Atlantic Canada, 1991. It revealed that R and D spending in Atlantic Canada is 35 per cent below over-all Canadian spending, 78 per cent below Ontario and 30 per cent below Quebec.
To close this gap a significant increase is required. The best incentive would be the situation where an entrepreneur could commit his or her own funds first, which would then yield a tax benefit.
The most effective method to encourage R and D expenditure is the ITC tax credit which is fully refunded
to CCPC. Presently the Atlantic Canadian rate is set at 35 per cent. This rate should be increased to 60 per cent. This would be a welcome boost for initiative and creativity in the Atlantic region. This sort of program would be an indication that this government supports regional development as well as competitiveness in the 1990s.

Mr. Speaker, it is important to recognize the need to establish a balance between economic development and environmental protection. The concept of sustainable development is being accepted in Canada and around the world as a means to achieve that vital balance.
Under the umbrella of the United Nations, the world community will soon join together in Brazil to consider the nature of the critical relationship between environment and development. A way must be found to ensure that new and effective environmental technology is available, not only to industrialized nations but also to developing countries. What is required in each country is a national environmental plan to define sustainable development objectives and describe appropriate processes.
The Canadian government has demonstrated leadership in this regard with the emergence of our own green plan. Our Prime Minister has demonstrated his commitment and leadership by confirming his attendance at the earth summit in June. We all know that we must balance development with environmental protection. Let us all work together to ensure a safer environment and a better world for our children.

Mr. Speaker, for several years I have been questioning the Minister of National Health and Welfare about breast implants and have asked the minister when he will provide answers to women who have had implants and who need help. The minister has consistently refused to help and has repeatedly implied that women with problems with their implants are isolated cases. Yesterday I received four calls about breast implants.

April 2, 1992
The first was from a reporter who said that she had been unable to find one woman who is satisfied with her implant.
The second was from a woman looking for a doctor who had some experience in removing implants because she does not want to be experimented on again.
The third was from a woman who was looking for a lawyer who knows something about the issue.
The fourth was a woman who had her implants removed and was not advised to send them directly from the hospital to a lab or a lawyer, thereby jeopardizing possible future lawsuits.
It is time for the minister to provide help for women with breast implants, instead of siding with the manufacturers through his continued silence.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, seniors across Canada were thrilled in the last few days to learn that the Government of Canada, in a most unusual fit of generosity, has granted them an awesome 37 cents a month increase in their pensions. These seniors are overwhelmed at this new-found government largess.
With those additional riches, a thrifty senior citizen can afford an extra one third loaf of bread or even a quarter of a litre of milk. With careful shopping, a prudent senior citizen might even be able to use the 37 cents to buy a can of beans.
If, on the other hand, their basic needs permit, this increase will mean a significant improvement in a senior's quality of life. A senior who saves the additional 37 cents every month will be able to go to a movie once every 18 months.
It will be hard for seniors to forget the government's generosity when the next election rolls around.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship; Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my colleague, the Secretary of State, accompanied by
Claude Taylor, chairman of the board of Air Canada, representatives of the private sector, volunteers and fellow members of Parliament, this morning officially launched Voyageurs Canada 92, a unique experience in the history of our country, in this 125th anniversary year. Voyageurs Canada 92 is thus in place, ready for the largest exchange program for young Canadians across the country.
I am very pleased that my constituency of Laval-Est is twinned with Edmonton North. This program will give nearly 37,000 young Canadians between the ages of 16 and 21 an opportunity to discover their country, its different regions and its people. Voyageurs Canada 92 is an investment in our collective future. I say to all those young people: Travel throughout our beautiful country, because you are its future. Have a good trip!

Mr. Speaker, this spring and fall some 37,000 young Canadians will celebrate Canada's 125th birthday by getting to know their country better through first-hand experience courtesy of Air Canada and the Secretary of State.
The 295 members of this House will twin with each other and will exchange young people from one part of Canada to another.
The program is called Voyageurs Canada 92. It will be the largest exchange program ever conducted for such a time period. Interested young people 16 to 21 years of age should contact their local MP.
And more good news on the national unity front. Today the Council for Canadian Unity released a survey done by Environics Research which revealed that 71 per cent of Canadians, including Quebecers, support the Beaudoin-Dobbie report.
Congratulations committee and Canadian youth.
April 2, 1992

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, once again, I would like to ask the Right Hon. Prime Minister a question.
Canadians wonder if this government will eventually stop confusing the issue. Yesterday, the Prime Minister said in this House that we would probably need a referendum, and the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs supported that view. However, right after Question Period, the Minister of Justice said that there cannot be a national referendum, only provincial referenda. Then, a few moments later, the Minister of State for Employment and Immigration stated that there should not be a referendum in Quebec with federal involvement, or something like that. And it goes on.
As I was saying yesterday, the Prime Minister spends money to tell Quebecers that the Beaudoin-Dobbie report is very good. But when the minister of defence returns from Paris, he will make a stop in Ottawa to tell us once again that the report is not good.
My question to the Prime Minister is: When will we have a prime minister who will take his responsibilities and tell Canadians that this confusion has lasted long enough and that the time has come to let all Canadians express themselves in a national referendum?

Mr. Speaker, I do not understand my friend's partisan flights of oratory. I do not understand them at all.
He asked me that question yesterday and I gave him an unequivocal answer on behalf of the government. It was the same the previous day. I do my best to provide him with complete and honest answers on an important issue. A few days ago, the hon. member seemed satisfied with my reply. If he has a problem with that, I will be pleased to help him.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened to the Prime Minister carefully yesterday. We have said on this side of the House that we want to help the government resolve the problem. Will he tell his ministers to shut up if they do not know what the policy of the government is?
Oral Questions
I was on a radio program this morning in Calgary and people were telling me: "When will they stop talking about the Constitution? We are fed up. We have economic problems in Canada".
The Minister of Justice talking about the Constitution says something contrary to the Prime Minister; the Minister of State for Employment and Immigration says the same thing.
When will we have a Prime Minister who will speak on behalf of his cabinet and tell his plan to the people of Canada so we can resolve the constitutional problems? When can we face the real problems that Canadians want us to resolve, to create jobs for the 1.5 million Canadians who want the economy to work?

Mr. Speaker, the Leader of Her Majesty's Loyal Opposition asks me a very strange question on the floor of the House of Commons: Will I tell the ministers of the Crown to shut up? The answer is absolutely not. This is a free Parliament, a democratic Parliament and that is why we are here.
If my hon. friend is suggesting that there has been a violation of government policy, then perhaps he could bring that to my attention.
I can tell my hon. friend that in the past, ministers in other governments perhaps ought to have spoken up, ought not to have accepted the party line on a very important matter, some 11 to 12 years ago. Perhaps we would not be in some of the difficulties we are today if others had stood up and said: "This is not good enough. We will not put up with this. Canada must be made whole from the very beginning".

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister after seven years in government will know that a government is a government. The government should speak with one voice. When somebody in the cabinet does not accept the word of the Prime Minister, the honourable thing to do is just to get out of the cabinet and speak outside the cabinet.
I would like to know when this Prime Minister will end this confusion and ask his government to have one constitutional policy so that we can resolve this problem that is bleeding Canadians? They want us to resolve the problem. The hesitation and ambivalence of this government is creating a desespoir among Canadians.

April 2, 1992
Oral Questions
The Prime Minister has nothing to lose. He just has to do his job and the people of Canada will be happy.

Mr. Speaker, I still do not understand why the Leader of the Opposition feels that on something this important he has to surround whatever criticism he may have with such needlessly partisan observations.
No.
Yes, on a question like this.
I want you to be the Prime Minister.

Oh, I see.
I will say that when this matter came up the last time, I came before the House in 1987, having negotiated a constitutional accord which I believed was in the best interests of Canada. I brought it before the House of Commons and we initiated a debate. It was supported very widely by almost all members of the House of Commons. When it was not fulfilled, pursuant to the obligations of the Constitution in 1982,1 came back and negotiated it again.
My hon. friend may have had disagreements with it, but I took the risks on behalf of Canada. I believed that Canadian unity was so important that we tried to achieve that degree of unanimity and unity. I brought it back again for full debate and support by members of the House of Commons.
It was approved by eight provinces representing 94 per cent of the Canadian population. That was a great exercise in Canadian democracy. It may not have been perfect, but it sought the end of bringing people together.
We did not succeed even though we achieved unanimity on two occasions, in 1987 and 1990. Some of the most eloquent support that we received was from members of my hon. friend's own party, and I thank those members again for that.
The fact of the matter is that we are faced with another challenge. I am going to commit every effort that I can and I invite my hon. friend to do the same thing, to make sure that at the end of the day there is one and only one important consideration, the unity of Canada. Not whether I am elected or re-elected, that is irrelevant. Not whether my hon. friend is elected or re-elected, that is irrelevant. The only important thing is Canada and the unity of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Prime Minister. For the second day in a row he has been trying to rewrite history and make excuses for his failure to successfully conclude an agreement. Whatever the circumstances, one thing is for sure, he made promises he was unable to keep. Those are the facts. And the person to blame for today's constitutional crisis is the Prime Minister, who made promises he failed to keep.
The Minister of the Environment knows that the Liberal Party-all members of the Liberal Party-tried very hard to obtain approval of the Charest report. It is clear that the dissenting voices were not on this side but on the other side of the House.
Mr. Speaker, my question is this: How can we expect to settle the constitutional question, when some Conservative ministers cannot seem to make up their minds? We know how hard it is for some of his ministers from Quebec to conform to cabinet discipline, but we are amazed that the Prime Minister cannot even control his Minister of Justice.
When will the Prime Minister manage to control his cabinet and ensure the government speaks with one voice?

Mr. Speaker, as a federalist and as a Canadian, I really do not understand how the hon. member can make these highly partisan comments on an issue that is so vital to the existence of our countiy.
He says we should not rewrite history. I agree. The events are there, and historians will make their own value judgments. The fact is that on June 9, 1990, at a televised meeting in Ottawa, the Prime Minister of Canada and 10 provincial premiers all 10, signed a constitutional document, pursuant to which they agreed to approve the Meech Lake accord or have it approved, either by referendum or by a vote in a legislative assembly by June 22.
In one province, all three leaders-NDP, Conservative and Liberal-expressed their approval of the Accord. But in the tenth province's legislature, the vote that was to take place, as agreed by the provincial premier when he signed the document, was cancelled at the very last minute. If the accord had been defeated by a vote in the legislature I would have said: Well, that's too bad, but at least the MPPs had a chance to say yes or no. However, the fact that the vote was cancelled at the veiy last minute was a very serious development.
April 2, 1992

I am not the one to rewrite history and I would ask my hon. friend to read up on his history before making these negative comments about me.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask another question of the Prime Minister because it is obvious that what is at stake here is the future of this country.
The unity of this country is very important. It seems to us on this side that the government has been confusing process with progress.
We have had the Spicer commission. We had the Beaudoin-Edwards committee. We had the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee. We have had six national conferences and many millions of dollars later we are asking and wondering where the government is going.
Very recently the Minister of Finance said in this House that the bad economy was linked with the unresolved constitutional crisis. Well, we would like to be sure that the government is going to come forward very soon with a solution to this constitutional crisis. Unfortunately, we do not see this coming.
When will the Prime Minister come with the united proposal from his cabinet, a uniform final proposal that all Canadians could vote on and agree?

Mr. Speaker, if the challenge were to bring forward a united proposal from the Government of Canada, that would be forthcoming. Perhaps my friend has forgotten under the 1982 Constitution that is no longer possible.
The primary obligation pursuant to the Constitution that was amended was that the Government of Canada meet with the provinces and agree with the provinces on constitutional amendments without which we do not have the constitutional authority to move ahead.
That is the heritage of 1982. I am not being critical. It is simply a fact of life which means we cannot simply stand up in the House of Commons and say we are going to propose such and such constitutional change without the approval of the provinces.
Oral Questions
The point that we have been making, and I think it is a reasonable point, is that we have engaged the process further to consultation with Canadians. They wanted royal commissions, parliamentary commissions, and the involvement of ordinary Canadians to the extent humanly possible. There were five major conferences, plus one that was devoted exclusively to aboriginal concerns. That was very important.
We are now meeting with the provinces with a view to seeing if we cannot come forward unanimously with a package that will meet all of the requirements of Canadians in terms of constitutional change.
I have indicated time and time again to my hon. friend-and I thought he agreed with this-that if we are unable to do this in spite of our best efforts then we will come before the House of Commons and report to him and our colleagues with a device designed to make sure that Canadians have an opportunity to speak for themselves in regard to this fundamental question.
I do not think there is any disagreement between my hon. friend and myself as to our ultimate objective. We are trying to do it in the most democratic and effective way possible.

Mr. Speaker, there are 1.5 million unemployed Canadians outside this House and another 1.5 million Canadians who are on some form of social assistance, many of whom have given up looking for work.
Today, Statistics Canada suggests there is a stall in the economic recovery, but the Conference Board of Canada goes further and calls it the slowest recovery from a recession in modern history. The Conference Board makes a direct link between the high unemployment and the recovery from the recession. Certainly the unemployed would agree with that.

April 2, 1992
Oral Questions
In its last budget the government has refused to invest in a program like a community infrastructure program to get people back to work. The government's programs clearly are not working. Employment is not increasing in this country. I want to ask the Prime Minister: When will the government bring forth a plan to get Canadians back to work?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. Leader of the New Democratic Party has been referring to the composite leading indicator, which I remind her has increased for nine consecutive months. It stayed level in the month of January, but I remind her that real gross domestic product grew in the month of January. Housing sales are up by some 14.5 per cent. New housing starts are up by some 11 per cent. Motor vehicle sales are up by some 7 per cent over the previous year.
There are indications of a strengthening U.S. economy, but I remind the hon. member that the economy is weak not only in Canada. It is weak in the United States. It is weak in the United Kingdom. It is weak in France. It is weak in Japan. It is a world-wide phenomenon.
I think the hon. member would agree with me that a number of initiatives were brought forth in the budget to help the manufacturing and processing sector, to improve the investment climate, to preserve jobs, and to create new jobs.

Mr. Speaker, Canadians understand that economies may be weak, but what they need is a strong government in Canada that will stand up for Canadians and put in place some programs that will get Canadians back to work.
This government acts as though it has absolutely no choice and that it is powerless to do anything. A number of suggestions have been put forward by the provinces, by this party and by others that would get Canadians back to work.
The Conference Board today has confirmed that the employment results "of the past months are nothing short of disastrous". That has to be a serious indictment of this government's policies.
One of the reasons is certainly the Canada-U.S. trade deal. We only have to look at what has happened with the Honda ruling, beef exports, beer, all the softwood countervail, and so on. Now we see computers and
textile industries being jeopardized by the proposed NAFTA deal.
I want to ask the Prime Minister: Given what is happening in Canada now, given what is happening to Canadian jobs, why is the government intent on expanding a trade deal to Mexico, taking a bad deal, the Canada-U.S. trade deal, and making it worse?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I presume from that my hon. friend would not have us at the table at all and that she would like to have the Mexicans and the Americans arrange a trade deal among themselves that could disadvantage Canada, that could disadvantage Canadian investment and investment in Canada.
That is simply not the position of this government. We also see some good opportunities for business in Mexico. I remind her that there was a trade show at the end of January. We were looking for some 75 companies to go to that trade show, but because of the opportunities that were there 206 Canadian companies went down.
Automotive products, telecommunications, environmental products and transportation are all products or services for which Canadian business people see good opportunities in Mexico and through Mexico into the rest of the South American market.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question for the minister. It is clear that this government has managed to export more Canadian jobs and products despite what the minister has to say.

I would like to ask the minister a question about a very specific area, textiles and electronics, industries that employ hundreds of thousands of people in this country. We learned that senior American and Canadian officials are saying that these industries are even more threatened than before because of the trade agreement between the United States, Canada and Mexico.
Here is my question for the minister. Surely it is time to end these negotiations. Once again, hundreds of thousands of jobs are at risk. Is the minister now prepared to end these negotiations, for the sake of Canadians and their jobs?
April 2, 1992
Protection all the way.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not understand how my hon. friend can say as a result of the free trade agreement there has been an export of jobs when our exports with the United States have gone up since 1988. Our trade surplus with the United States has gone up since 1988. The facts do not support the rhetoric that she is using.
As far as the particular question she has posed on the rules of origin for textiles and for electronics, she may be surprised to hear that she and I are in agreement. We are opposed to the position that is on the table between the Americans and the Mexicans, and we are fighting that. We are fighting that because the advice that we have received from those industries is that it would be negative for the position of those industries in Canada and in seeking access to those markets.
That is precisely why we are at the table: to get a good deal for Canada, a good deal for these industries, and to make sure that the national interest is protected.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister will know that the Leader of the Opposition and indeed members of this party have publicly acknowledged and applauded the position of the Prime Minister in Quebec last week and the posture of the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs in Alberta last week. We have applauded the Prime Minister and the constitutional affairs minister in coming around to the position that we have consistently taken on a national referendum and the need for a national referendum.
Through five questions today from the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Papineau about the division, the conflict and the contradiction within the Prime Minister's cabinet, the Prime Minister has not once said or acknowledged the need for a cabinet to be united on this important question.
Does the Prime Minister agree with those of us on this side of the House that it is important for a cabinet to
Oral Questions
speak with one voice on this question if we are to expect a resounding single and unified voice from the people of Canada on the need to keep this country together?

Mr. Speaker, I thank my hon. friend for his original comments, his prefatory remarks. I acknowledged earlier yesterday the constructive views of the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Papineau in regard to some important aspects of national unity. When he talked about the division, conflict and contradiction, I thought he was talking about his caucus for a while and not necessarily anybody else's.
With regard to the question of unity, no political party on any great issue, at least not in recent Canadian history, has had total agreement on everything, but in the seven and one-half years I have had the privilege of being Prime Minister I have been very grateful for the solidarity and the support I have received when I have had occasion to speak for my party and my caucus. That has been true from the beginning, with some exceptions, and it remains true today.
With regard to the question as to whether the caucus and the party is united on the important question of the unity of Canada, there is no question about that.
Is it united on the question of putting forward new constitutional proposals that will meet the legitimate aspirations of Canadians from all across the country? There is no problem there. Is it united on the question of this being done within respectable and reasonable time frames that we are all familiar with? There is no problem there.
However, given the constraints of 1982 which force us to deal with the premiers to achieve a constitutional agreement, how it is done gives rise to differences of opinion. Those differences of opinion are not fundamental to the issue of Canadian unity. All of us in our own way are seeking to do the right thing, namely to keep the country together, as I think my hon. friend is.

Mr. Speaker, there are thousands of Canadians including many on this side of the House who are willing to participate in a crusade for Canada, but we have to know what the game plan is.

April 2, 1992
Oral Questions
