Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to rise in the House today to add my comments to those we have already heard.
It is about time that we honoured on the floor of this House those people who did what they did with respect to helping the survivors of that crash and the families of the victims to live through this terrible experience.
I compliment my colleague from Kenora-Rainy River. I listened very carefully to his words. The amendment
that was just passed by unanimous consent certainly addresses those issues that have not to this point in time been considered by this House, nor have they been referred to on the floor of the House.
I also compliment my colleague from Thunder Bay- Atikokan for rising in his place to support the motion and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport who added his support to the motion. I thank both those two gentlemen and my colleague for bringing this matter before the House.
The substance of the motion today is to talk about deregulation and how it affected all modes of travel within our country, particularly air. This motion comes at an appropriate time inasmuch as we are considering the Moshansky report.
What we are talking about here when we talk about deregulation is deregulation coupled with financial restraint that happened at the same time. It is like trying to combine oil and water; it just does not mix. At this time, suffice it to say, when we try to combine those ingredients we need strong ministerial support and strong ministerial direction to ensure that those people charged with the responsibility of regulatory control and with the responsibility of providing safety to the air-travelling public of this country have had the support of those at the highest decision-making level and to ensure that they were not overworked and their responsibilities in investigating and training were followed through. Unfortunately this was not done. I hope all of us on all sides of the House have learned a lesson from this terrible tragedy.
Out of every tragedy there emerge Canadians who truly should be honoured as my colleague from Kenora has just stated. Not only should they be honoured but recognized on the floor of this House in some tangible way through which we can continue to show on behalf of all Canadians the thanks which they rightly deserve.
I know my time is short. Let me just talk about the three areas I think are important. One is the support shown by all the people from the town of Diyden led by then Mayor Tom Jones. He has shown leadership over the years as mayor of that wonderful small community. Their support and leadership were evident. In very adverse and terrible weather circumstances they were able to accommodate not only the families of the victims of this terrible tragedy, but also those who survived the tragedy.
April 2, 1992

I had the opportunity to sit through the hearing process in Thunder Bay, in Dryden and some of the hearings in Toronto. When I heard the evidence that was educed at the hearing and in the hearing process I could not help but admire every person who made a contribution from the town of Dryden. I, along with my colleagues on this side of the House, certainly give heartfelt thanks to everyone who made a substantial contribution, including the leadership of the mayor of Dryden.
Sonia Hartwick was the sole surviving member of the crew. What else can be said? We heard the evidence at the hearings and looked at the pain that she was going through in order to give this evidence again. She relived this terrible tragedy not only through her own evidence but through the evidence of those who survived and those who saw her perform in a very professional way and in a way that showed her empathy for the people who needed her help at that particular time.
I lack for a better word but, if I can paraphrase, if ever I have seen a heroine in my lifetime it was truly evident in her performance in this trying time. She truly deserves the thanks of all Canadians. I hope, as my colleague has stated, there will be something in a more tangible form to honour Sonia Hartwick who in our judgment is truly a heroine of this terrible tragedy.
We watched the evidence given by the survivors and Ms. Hartwick. We looked at her husband and her family during this tragedy. There should be some mention made of them. We saw the pain that they were also going through as their wife or daughter was reliving this terrible experience. As father of three girls you always put yourself, as you well know, Mr. Speaker, in the position of what you would do. I can only say on behalf of her husband and her parents how proud I am sure they must have been of her during that critical time. They should be truly thanked for the support they gave her after the tragedy and I am sure they continue to give her.
There is another group of people who are truly worthy of the thanks of the Canadian people. Mr. Justice Virgil Moshansky conducted this tremendous in-depth inquiry not only into the tragedy itself at Dryden but a further
Supply
inquiry into air traffic safety and how the methodology of accident investigation is conducted in this country. He has shown, through the four volumes of his report, that there are certainly deficiencies in the process.
The work and the dedication Mr. Justice Moshansky undertook in this three-year process along with everyone that was associated, particularly the commission council, Mr. von Veh, certainly deserve, as my colleague has stated, the thanks of those of us who travel a lot on Canadian airlines and the international air community. I am sure they will take the sum and substance of this report and use it as a guide or a model by which all future investigations into air disasters will be conducted.
Just as an aside, I was truly impressed in the first several hearings that Mr. Justice Moshansky conducted a coroner-type inquest into the why, when, where, and by what means all of the victims came to their death.
I had to draw a parallel at that time because we were also involved in the Gander situation in 1985. It has been under constant review. I could not help but compare the quality of the investigative process conducted by Justice Moshansky and Mr. von Veh to the way the Gander inquiry was conducted. That one little episode could have helped family members in the Gander situation. Had the people responsible for the investigation in Gander even gone to the fundamental principle of conducting a coroner-type inquest into the reasons and by what means those soldiers came to their death, they would have satisfied the dilemma all of us not only in Canada but in the United States find ourselves in today because of an improper investigation.
That shows the tremendous importance and contribution of Mr. Justice Moshansky, his commission counsel, Mr. Frederick von Veh, and all the others involved. The lawyers representing the families, Mr. Chris Knutsen and Mr. Sandy Zaitzess, made a substantial contribution.
I appreciate the opportunity to have voiced my concerns.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Belsher (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to address a question to the hon. member opposite.

April 2, 1992
Supply
I have listened to the questions asked in this House since Justice Moshansky's report was given to the public domain. I have also read the motion we have today. It seems we have a conspiracy which says the total fault of the aeroplane accident was deregulation.
I recall reading in the Moshansky report that there was also some error on the part of the people who worked for the airline in that they did not follow through some of their own prescribed procedures.
I am wondering how he could rationalize those two things and make sure there is a balance on the public record for the Canadian people to look at rather than see only one position put forward from this House as we have seen in the last couple of weeks, that it was an accident purely because of deregulation. Would the hon. member care to comment?

Mr. Speaker, I thank my colleague for that question. We worked very closely together when he was the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport and I was on the transport committee.
He will recall that our committee was instrumental in changing the deficiencies in what was then known as the Canadian Aviation Safety Board. We brought in a multimodal new concept with respect to the investigation of any accident involving trains, pipelines, or in the air or sea.
He will recall that we listened to the evidence given by Captain Norm Vindon of the Canadian Airline Pilots Association and many other people. What really came through to all of us was that there was no one single contributing factor to any accident today. Everything is just too complicated. I appreciate what the member has just asked, but I ask him to take his mind back to the time of that investigative process. It is not one single incident that causes an accident.
I would like to answer the question on deregulation. Although we had deregulation at the time of this incident and the Gander incident, it was one of the major contributing factors. It was not the sole factor, not the only reason why we had this disaster, but it was one of the contributing aspects that caused the accident in Dryden to happen. There were others. I believe the report states there were others. The report also states that it is one of the contributors toward this unfortunate incident and I hope, as I said earlier, that we can all learn from this situation so that it will not happen again.

Mr. Speaker, I want to ask my colleague from Thunder Bay-Nipigon two questions. As I understood, he indicated it was not only deregulation but also financial restraint, including lack of support from the highest ministerial authorities, that together, working in concert, had a potential, extremely negative impact on what occurred. I want to know whether I understood that.
Second, while we speak of Gander and Dryden, and they were terrible tragedies, Canadians are also interested in whether deregulation, financial restraint, and lack of appropriate government support could lead to certain problems in other areas as well.
He could perhaps give two quick comments.

Mr. Speaker, I thank my colleague for the question. As I stated earlier, the financial constraints that were imposed gave an unholy mix here which was almost like oil and water. On the one hand we have financial restraints being imposed by the Minister of Transport and the government through its endeavours. On the other hand we have deregulation. What does that mean?
It means that in the open market concept or the free enterprise concept anyone could enter the system. What we faced on the other end of the spectrum was a regulatory body which was very important within the air safety in this country and which was confined. Through the reports, the numbers were being cut back rather than being really even kept.
What we have here is a huge workload and a smaller amount of people who could do the work adequately.
Justice Moshansky addresses that issue when he says it was an unworkable combination. That is why I said at the outset that it was ministerial decision-making at the highest level that should be looked at.

Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to participate in this debate today because I am proud of the government's achievements in transportation. A strong and competitive transportation system is vital for the development of all regions of Canada. I must also applaud our government's efforts to reform the laws and regulations that apply to the transportation system. This vital change has been long awaited. I am confident that it will enable Canada to remain competitive throughout the 1990s, while providing Canadians with safe and reliable transportation services.

April 2, 1992

The principal objectives of the reform of the economic regulations that apply to transportation in Canada are to stimulate competition, to improve the price and range of transportation services and to encourage the development of key economic sectors in our society. As competition among carriers intensifies, the transportation sector becomes more efficient and effective. Our products thus become more competitive on both domestic and international markets.
Regulations have played a very important role in Canada's social and economic development. They met a need to protect the public interest and ensure the provision of adequate services at a time when markets were simply too weak and underdeveloped to count on competition.
Today, our transportation system, like other industries, has grown and matured. Regulatory protection is no longer needed. Furthermore, competition is much stronger today in all sectors than it was just a few years ago.
These reforms were necessary for Canada to remain competitive in the world economy. The area of Canada is extremely large, second only to Russia. Yes, Canada has many and varied natural resources and a large manufacturing sector, but marketing all these products requires long-distance transportation. Efficient transportation is therefore critical.
In Canada, the share of transportation in the total cost is 1 or 2 per cent higher than in most of the countries with which we compete. On average, transportation accounts for about 5 per cent of the total cost of Canadian products. For resources like coal, pulp, paper, and potash, transportation makes up about 20 or 30 per cent of the delivery price and even 45 per cent for some coal exports.
Of course, we can do nothing to change the long distances that our products have to be shipped to market. It is therefore crucial that we overlook no factor in our control that would keep our costs higher than they could be.
Supply
In late 1984, we determined that the transportation regulatory regime was an obstacle rather than an incentive to competition, both in Canada and abroad. Our regulations prevented the transportation industry from attaining the efficiency of which it was capable.
The main difficulty was reconciling the interests of shippers and carriers in improving the package of reforms. Shippers, especially captive shippers, were offered competitive choices through initiatives like competitive line prices and higher interconnection limits. Carriers obtained the management freedom that they sought, which lets them sign confidential contracts and not have to report prices, for example.
The legislative provisions are based on the following principles: First, safety remains the top priority. Transportation safety will be subordinate to no other objective. Second, transportation services exist to meet the needs of shippers and travellers. We cannot consider these services an end in themselves. Third, as much as possible, market forces and not the government should determine what services will be offered at what price. We will thus have a more efficient and economical system and be able to provide shippers and travellers with a wide range of services. Reducing the regulatory burden and government intervention will encourage transportation companies to innovate. Fourth, economic regulation must continue to protect the public interest as often as necessary. Given the weakness of markets in remote regions like the far north, for example, some regulations must remain to ensure orderly development of these markets and guarantee essential services. The disabled must have fair and decent access to the transportation system.
Finally, any regulation that remains in effect should be open, accessible and economical in time and money.
Let us now look at what has happened. First, the two basic laws, the 1987 National Transportation Act and the Motor Vehicle Transport Act, have been in place for over four years. Transport Canada and the National Transportation Agency are following events closely.

April 2, 1992
Supply
One concern raised in the debate on the new National Transportation Act was that regulatory controls were needed to ensure adequate service. So far, everything indicates that the markets are mature enough and strong enough to benefit from increased competition.
In air transport, for example, there is strong competition, not only on the long-haul domestic markets but also in all regions of Canada, with the result that the frequency of service has increased.
The reform of economic regulations has made it possible to better adjust the size of aircraft to passenger demand on short hauls and for services to small communities.
The greater number of flights and the better service that turbo-prop aircraft operators can therefore provide to travellers have dissipated the fears of a loss of services by jet airplanes.
These services are expanding in the north, where some regulations were maintained to protect already established airline companies, as well as vulnerable markets. Also, the legislation gives the authority to ensure essential air services. So far, it has not been necessary to use this safety device.
As regards the railroad industry, shippers and carriers work jointly. More innovative services are offered, as was hoped when we introduced this legislation.
The confidential contracts have proven to be very effective and popular marketing tools.
As you know, the interprovincial trucking business remains a provincial jurisdiction. As expected, achieving uniformity at the national level proved to be a challenge. However, the system works and truckers get some relief as regards regulations, which translates into savings of time and money. This situation is also beneficial to shippers, since they have access to a wider choice of carriers and services.
The reform also included the marine sector. The provisions of the Shipping Conferences Exemption Act of 1987 protect the public interest while also promoting greater competition.
I also want to mention an important reform regarding transport and handicapped people. Thanks to the co-operation of all members, Bill C-131 was passed on July 7, 1988. Those amendments to the National Transportation Act enabled us to determine and implement accessibility
standards for every mode, something which was not previously possible.
Our objective is to ensure that handicapped people can use means of transportation that meet their needs while preserving their dignity. It goes without saying that the new economic legislation will not bring about a slacking off of the government controls regarding safety. The new National Transportation Act puts safety among its top priorities; in fact, safety is the main reason justifying the existence of the Department of Transport. I might add that numerous initiatives were undertaken in recent years to ensure and improve safety for every transport mode in Canada.
The measures that we have taken, as well as the global changes to the act are part of the gradual transformation that our transport network has been undergoing for numerous years.
Before Confederation, transport was a real challenge in all our regions. A vast uneven territory needed some links. Our original needs were met with the construction of a transcontinental railroad, which was the dream of Sir John Alexander Macdonald. Then, there was the St. Lawrence Seaway in 1959 and the Trans-Canada Highway in 1962 which both contributed tremendously to economic expansion and transports in our country. Our airline companies and our communication networks are expanding, thereby bringing the regions closer, to the point that we are now all neighbours within a great nation.
The transport modes will continue to play an essential part in the years leading to the next century. The transport network of the future will have to meet five fundamental criteria: (1) it will be safe; (2) it will be accessible to all travellers, including handicapped people; (3) it will be efficient and effective in the sense that it will represent the most judicious use of each transport mode: the aircraft, the railway, the automobile, the truck and the bus; (4) it will meet the needs of shippers and travellers; (5) it will be innovative, both in terms of use of technology as well as provision of services.
In conclusion, our new regulation policy has promoted a climate of competition which has benefited our country. In this fast-changing global village that is today's world, Canadians cannot act like ostriches and bury their heads in the sand, hoping that memories will drive away today's realities. That is why our government has given Canadians the means to take advantage of new opportunities and to face the challenges ahead.
April 2, 1992

Mr. Speaker, I want to begin by saying that I do not much like people who say: "I told you so". I am going to say it anyway. I told you so.
Not only I, but dozens of others, knowledgeable experts nationally and internationally in transportation, warned the Conservative government and the previous Liberal government repeatedly about the problems they would face bringing in deregulation. Neither the present government nor its predecessor listened.
When the transport committee was holding hearings for about a year and a half on the white paper called "Freedom to Move", which really meant deregulation, I said that the government was going to kill some more people. It has.
I served for 21 years continuously on the transport committee. I have 15 years experience on Canadian Pacific Railway. I know a little bit about it, but I sure as heck am not an expert.
My problem, in those 21 years on the transport committee, was being continually surrounded by amateurs who did not know one end of a boxcar from the other. My hon. friend, the Solicitor General, whom I like very much, I must rank among those who did not know the difference.
Transport was the largest department in the government the last time I checked. If it is not now, it is in the top three. Here is the kind of attention and priority this government since 1984 and the previous Liberal government gave to that department.
We have had 13 transport ministers in the past 24 years. There were six Tories in eight years and seven Liberals in 15 years. They served anywhere from one month to 44 months. The one with the record of 44 months was the unlamented Otto Lang, who started all this. They are fine people. I like them individually and there is nothing personal about this.
They were amateurs, they were in a department in which they were not the slightest bit interested. It was not their cup of tea but they had no choice but to do whatever the officials of the department said because they did not know any better.
Supply
We have had seven or eight Ministers of State for Transport. They were supposed to relieve and take some of the huge load off the backs of the Ministers of Transport. None was any help.
Going through and recalling what occurred when the transport committee held those hearings on Freedom to Move, and thinking of the witnesses who appeared, it was obvious then that the new Conservative government was on an ideological binge that the bottom line syndrome, deregulated transportation, competition and so-called free enterprise would be the priority, the guiding policy of the government.
We in the NDP, and before that the CCF, are accused of being ideologues. When it comes to ideology, we were amateurs compared to these birds.
When one looks at trucking, it is a jungle out there. There are thirteen jurisdictions with different regulations and rules. Under our Constitution, interprovincial and international trucking are under the jurisdiction of the national government. It vacated it and turned it over to the provinces and territories. When it brought in deregulation, it was warned and told not to do so until it had some co-ordination and identical rules and regulations regarding safety, load limits, speed limits, whatever, jointly arrived at by the provinces, territories and the national government. Some efforts have been made but most of it still has not happened.
Regarding the railroads, the most efficient and environmentally friendly mode of transportation, the government is doing all it can to abandon railway lines. We particularly noticed this in western Canada, although I note it is now happening to a large degree in Ontario and Quebec over the last couple of years.
Grain has to be trucked further because of the abandoned branch lines in the prairie provinces. It means that you have to have larger trucks. One hundred cars of grain will move as much grain as three to four hundred trucks. The beauty of the ideological binge the government is on is that the railroads get out from undermaintaining and improving railway branch lines. The government gets out of its responsibility of making them run a good railroad, and the costs are shifted to the provinces and the municipalities.

April 2, 1992
Supply
There are the airlines. I want to point out two of the witnesses who appeared before the committee when we dealt with the white paper and with legislation. We had difficulty getting one of them accepted by the committee as a witness on his own. He appeared as a member of another delegation. I refer to one John Nance, and I invite my colleagues to read his book. Mr. Nance is a commercial airline pilot, a recognized national and international expert. He was on television the other night as a result of the New York incident. He sure is no socialist but he warned, pleaded with and begged us not to bring in deregulation until we have everything in place necessary to keep safe, efficient and properly maintained and equipped airlines and staff.
He urged us not to make the same mistake that was made in the United States. We have to have in place a sufficient number of air traffic controllers and back-up controller staff. We have to have in place a sufficient number of civil aircraft inspectors. We have to have in place increased training of air traffic controllers and civilian aircraft inspectors. It takes several years to become either one of those. They are high-stress jobs. Some of them do not last long. They have to be replaced fairly frequently. He told us that.
Then the immediate past president, head of the Federal Aviation Administration in the United States, the governing body of airlines down there, the regulatory body similar to our CTC, said the same thing. He urged us not to make the mistakes that the United States made by deregulating too quickly before government, airlines, airports and regulators were ready and prepared for it. We got the same message from him. Again, the government would not listen and chose not to believe him.
The figures the Minister of Transport cited were the statistics for all aircraft movements. He did not tell about just the commercial airlines. The figures are abysmal. The figures prove that deregulation has harmed safety in the air and among commercial aircraft in Canada.
To some people who have not learned anything since, the theoiy was, and with some it still is, that deregulation would increase competition, would lower fares and give a better deal for the consuming public. What has happened? It is so ridiculous it is laughable.
I have a list here of 39 carriers in the United States. Of those 39, 10 are bankrupt, some pretty large ones too. Eastern Airlines, for example, which used to be one of the largest, went belly-up. There were 17 takeovers by the present existing airlines and 1 merger. Out of those
39,10	are still operating. So much for increased competition.
Then we come to Canada. Prior to deregulation we had four regional carriers, medium-sized airline operations. A couple of them were doing okay. One was borderline, one was having troubles. We had Air Canada, Canadian Pacific and Wardair.
Max Ward was one of those who appeared before the committee more than once. He is a nice guy. He even gave me a ride in his limousine back to the hotel after a hearing one night when we had a knock down, drag 'em out argument. Max said to us: "Leave me alone. I don't want any subsidies. I don't need all these regulations. All I want to do is operate my charter airline. I'm not interested in domestic routes." Within a year or so of deregulation, who was down in Ottawa pleading and begging for domestic routes? Max Ward, that great entrepreneur of the international charter airlines.
I do not know that Max was hurt all that much personally, but we know what happened to Wardair. It was sort of taken over. I doubt if it got its money, its market value. Canadian Airlines International Ltd. acquired Wardair in 1989.
To go back to 1983, Pacific Western took over Time Air. In 1984, CP Air acquired Eastern Provincial Airways. Innocan Inc. acquired Nordair. A year or so later, Innocan, which had acquired Nordair, was taken over. In 1985, Air Canada and Pacific Western each acquired 24.5 per cent of Air Ontario. So much for competition. Canadian Pacific helped establish Nordair Metro. So much for some more competition. Nordair Metro acquired Quebecair. Talk about banditry. Bank robbers are amateurs.
In 1986 Air Canada acquired 49 per cent of Air Nova. There went some more competition. PWA in 1987 acquired CP Air for $300 million. It was great for the CP Limited shareholders but did not do much for increased competition due to deregulation.
April 2, 1992

The more one goes through this you do not know whether to break into hysterical laughter or throw up.
In 1988 Air Canada acquired 90 per cent of Northwest Territorial Airlines. Now it is into the territories. In 1990 Air Canada was reported to have outbid TWA to acquire Air Toronto, a commuter carrier to some U.S. cities. This sale was not completed by the end of May 1990 but I think it has been since.
What happened? We have two airlines that acquired several other outfits that were jerkwater, fly-by-night, two-bit operations. They are now called Canadian Airlines' partners and Air Canada's partners. Some partners. All those partners can do is take over the short haul, small numbers routes at the orders of Canadian or Air Canada.
Some of the flights out of the smaller and mediumsized cities in Canada, and I use as an example my city of Regina, are the short-haul routes: Regina-Saskatoon-Edmonton-Calgary-Winnipeg. The planes are not held together with chewing gum and rubber bands but they are propeller driven and might go 280 to 300 nautical miles per hour. It is a lesser service. But under deregulation we are supposed to get better service. This is a lesser service.
As we predicted and as the government was warned during their white paper discussions, it would mean lesser and poorer service to the small and middle sized cities in Canada. The government conveniently ignored that and forgot that there is more to Canada than Montreal, Toronto, Halifax and Vancouver.
If the government is really serious about safety being its number one priority, and we have heard that from every one of the 13 ministers of transport we have had in 24 years, that is less than two years each. One of them, the hon. member for Vegreville, a good buddy who sat on the committee with me for a number of years, only served nine months one period, just barely the gestation period. But if it is deadly serious, why does the government not fill the 70 vacant safety inspector positions, as pointed out by the aircraft operations group which represents the 500 civil aviation inspectors who work for Transport Canada and the Transportation Safety Board? Seventy unfilled positions for inspectors. Why did the
Supply
Minister of Transport not announce yesterday those positions were being filled?
Remember a couple of years ago the government brought 40-some air traffic controllers who had been fired in the United States to Canada, gave them a refresher course and put them to work because we were desperate for air traffic controllers. If it is deadly serious, it will hire, train and put to work the dozens more air traffic controllers that we desperately need.
Deregulation has been a disaster. It will continue to be so until we re-regulate and enforce what is required to keep our civil air traffic safer than it is now.

Mr. Speaker, I am always amazed at the amount of knowledge that my colleague, the member for Regina-Lumsden, has about transportation. With very few notes he is able to remind us of a number of things that people have said and done over not just the deregulation debate of the last six to eight years, but for a greater period of time.
I say that by way of a preamble because I want to ask him about statements made by the head of Canadian Airlines, Rhys Eyton, when he promised that when Wardair was taken over it would continue to operate as Wardair. It would not be gobbled up, it would not become part of Canadian Airlines.
I am going to ask my colleague for his interpretation of the words of that same individual today, when he says that American Airlines buying 25 per cent of Canadian will allow Canadian to operate independently, that Canadian will not be gobbled up in any way by American Airlines. I am wondering if he could pass on his wisdom of those kinds of statements in terms of the reality of them.

Mr. Speaker, I thank my hon. friend. One thing I can say about chief executive officers not only of airlines, but also of many other corporations which appeared before the transport committee in my years, is that most of them to make a buck would run over their own mothers if they had to.
Nobody believed Rhys Eyton concerning Wardair, but that was the pitch he made to the government and that was the pitch he made to the CTC and he got away with it. All of Max Ward's charter routes were long gone before very long.

As far as I am concerned and the position of the New Democratic Party is concerned, what is required is for Air Canada and Canadian Airlines to merge and let the transport commission carry out its duties as the enforcer and regulator and guardian of consumers' rights.
Instead of that, we have Mr. Eyton now crawling on his hands and knees to American Airlines, which you can bet will get 25 per cent ownership of Canadian Airlines. I will make a little prediction. I hope I turn out to be wrong, but in the life of this Parliament, before the next election, this government will allow a foreign airline to take up to 50 per cent ownership of a Canadian airline. Canada is trying to copy the great U.S. of A. We have lots of geography, lots of climate, not too many people. The only way we are going to operate more than one airline nationally and make money is by increasing fares by half again.
When I was first elected to Parliament, the round-trip economy fare, Regina to Ottawa was $126. Now the round trip regular economy fare is just about $1,000.
If anything proves that deregulation does not work, if anything proves that this country cannot afford a multiplicity of jerkwater, fly-by-night, overnight airlines, the experience of the last eight years should be enough. Surely a brick wall does not have to fall on the government, but I am afraid it will have to, and that brick wall will be called an election.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank the member for Regina-Lumsden for going through an exercise, certainly he has years and years of experience on the transport committee. I enjoyed his presentation, which in the beginning talked about the concern of starting with three nationals and four regionals, and the concern of coming down to two, and then his recommendation to bring it down to one. So I will have to examine Hansard tomorrow to follow the logic of that particular argument.
Let me say at the outset that Canada's aviation safety record is among the best in the world. A major accident, any accident, serves to remind us that aviation losses are unacceptable to the public and to any government. All Canadians grieve for the survivors and families of the victims of the tragic crash at Diyden. We are grateful to Judge Virgil Moshansky and the members of the commission for their tireless hard work and dedication in preparing the report that was released last week.
Now that the report has been released, Transport Canada has initiated a thorough, top priority examination of each of its recommendations. The report contained 191 recommendations, of which 35 have already been implemented by Transport Canada. There are 58 recommendations with which the department agrees and for which action is under way.
Seventy-three of the recommendations have been referred to the government-industry implementation team and the remaining 25 which deal broadly with legislation, the Transportation Safety Board and Transport Canada, are under review by the government.
Aviation safety is a product of a partnership of industry, government, unions and passengers. The work of the commission of inquiry has underscored the need for sustaining and strengthening these partnerships to ensure Canadian skies are safe.
Justice Moshansky's investigation is notable not only as an exhaustive study, but also as a constructive analysis which has contributed to our ongoing efforts to maintain and enhance aviation safety in this country. This report is not just a document to be taken under advisement; it is something that must be acted upon and Transport Canada is doing that.
The department's commitment has already been demonstrated by its actions in response to the 17 recommendations contained in the commission's two interim reports. These include key recommendations concerning the clean wing concept and new regulations governing the inspection of aircraft for the presence of ice, snow or frost. The Department of Transport is continually reviewing all aspects of its aviation safety operations and taking corrective action to ensure the system's safety. In 1987 the new National Transportation Act was passed to ease economic regulation of the transportation industry,
April 2, 1992

but I would like to assure this House that safety was not deregulated and air safety had not been compromised.
Since 1981 statistics compiled and released by the Transportation Safety Board show that there has been a 35 per cent decrease in aviation accidents. As the demand for efficient, affordable transportation continues to grow, transportation safety remains the top priority at Transport Canada.
Each year the department devotes a great deal of time, energy and resources to maintain and improve the safety of Canada's national transportation system. This commitment is especially important with respect to aviation. The department remains responsive and diligent in ensuring aviation safety. As I have said, aviation safety is a shared responsibility. Everyone involved in aviation has that responsibility: the aircraft designers, the builders, the technicians, engineers, the pilots, flight attendants, air traffic controllers, the regulators, executive and administrators. All have a direct professional and personal interest in aviation safety. This requires that all participants work together to promote safe operating practices in all aviation activities.
Transport Canada is responsible for the following: to develop and ensure effective safety regulations; to develop and operate air navigation and air traffic control systems; for promoting the use of practices which exceed the regulated standards; and finally, working together with other agencies to monitor the performance of air traffic networks and identify areas where safety can be improved.
Transport Canada also sets out the rules and safety standards for operating aircraft in Canada. It licenses pilots, commercial operators, flying schools, airports, aircraft, aircraft manufacturers and maintenance personnel. These safety standards are upheld through regular inspections of aircraft and safety audits of companies.
The foundation of Canada's aeronautics legislation is the Aeronautics Act which was substantially amended in
Supply
1985 following several years of analysis and public consultation. The amendments to the act not only introduced the most progressive aviation safety legislation in Canada, they enabled Transport Canada to better maintain a consistent watch over aeronautical activities.
The Aeronautics Act has just been amended again to further strengthen and improve safety regulations, including a provision for the introduction of urgent safety regulations in a more timely manner.
Transport Canada monitors the performance of the air transportation network and identifies areas where safety can be improved. The department also constantly monitors the air traffic control system.
Since economic regulatory reform was introduced five years ago, Transport Canada has undertaken many safety related initiatives. First, the $800 million radar modernization project, which is nearing completion, will provide the entire air traffic control radar surveillance system.
Second, the $660 million Canadian automated air traffic system called CAATS, which will be completed by 1995, will provide pilots and controllers with improved control capabilities.
Third, the air traffic controller training capacity has been doubled at the Transport Canada training institute. The nation-wide complement of air traffic controllers will be fully met by 1994. The current level is 90 per cent of the requirement of 2,200 controllers.
Fourth, the new air traffic flow management programs are ensuring traffic volumes are kept at manageable levels in air space around our busiest airports in Toronto, Vancouver, Winnipeg, and Montreal.
A new aeronautics code is being implemented. It deals with standard operating procedures for air carriers, restraint systems for flight attendants and carry-on baggage limitations, among others. Mr. Speaker, I do not know if you get frustrated, but sometimes I am amazed that some passengers seem to have eight arms when they are carrying on some of their luggage.
April 2, 1992

Supply
A special project has also been established to explore and participate in discussions with the Federal Aviation Administration and the joint aviation authorities of Europe to harmonize aviation rules.
Transport Canada Aviation was also reconstructed in 1991 to provide one focal point for the management of aviation related matters in each of the six regions. Also, a government industry task force on air carrier inspections was established in the fall of last year to review and recommend improvements in the manner in which audits, inspections and the general surveillance of the aviation industry is conducted. Finally, inspector training for air carrier audits has also been improved.
These are just some of the measures Transport Canada has taken to ensure safe air transportation in Canada.
I spoke earlier of shared responsibility for air safety. Air carriers are, of course, responsible for ensuring the safe operation of their aircraft at all times. Where icing conditions exist, regulations require a mandatory preflight inspection of an aircraft. Transport Canada has developed a mandatory surface contamination training package which all commercial air carriers must provide to personnel involved in flight operations. In addition, air carriers must have approved training programs for both flight and ground personnel in not only de-icing but also anti-icing procedures.
To ensure that pilots understand the implications of wing contamination, Transport Canada amended the air regulations and air navigation orders in November 1990 to prohibit the take-off of an airplane unless its critical surfaces are free of frost, ice or snow. The amendments also require that flight crews receive annual training on the effects of surface contamination on their aircraft.
In 1987, Transport Canada developed a new national company information system, a computerized system that documents air carrier information and tracks critical activity to strengthen Transport Canada's aviation auditing capabilities. To streamline and standardize its audit procedures, Transport Canada also undertook in December 1991 an extensive review of its audit procedures and has published a manual of regulatory audits which addresses all the shortcomings identified by the commission of inquiry.
Transport Canada and the airlines have agreed in principle on a centralized de-icing facility at Pearson International Airport. Work is progressing on technical and environmental approvals. In most cases, air carriers apply de-icing or anti-icing fluids before the aircraft departs for the runway. In severe conditions, if there is a delay between the time the aircraft is de-iced and the time the aircraft is given final clearance for take-off, the effects of the de-icing fluids may deteriorate rapidly. As a result, Transport Canada has implemented gate-hold procedures at Pearson where heavy traffic may cause unacceptable departure delays. Under these procedures, aircraft are held at the gate until a firm take-off time is assigned, ensuring take-off directly following de-icing. Delays between de-icing and take-off will virtually be eliminated by a new dedicated de-icing facility to be constructed at Pearson.
I would like to take my final moments to point out some of the important facts about Transport Canada's inspections and audit procedures.
Transport Canada carries out a number of activities to ensure that aviation companies comply with aviation regulation standards. Aviation regulation inspectors maintain ongoing surveillance of the aviation community on a regular basis. Monitoring activities are often carried out in conjunction with such activities as pilot proficiency checks, in-flight inspections and ramp checks.
In addition to routine monitoring activities, officials carry out detailed inspection of specific aspects of a company's operation as well as comprehensive company audits at regularly scheduled interviews.
I am sure all hon. members are aware of the important work, the crucial work, carried out by inspectors. This work force has increased since deregulation. The number of air carrier inspectors has increased by an average of 6 per cent per year and air worthiness staff has increased by 4 per cent during each of the past five years.
I would like to point out another initiative undertaken by Transport Canada, the Annual Canadian Aviation Safety Seminar, which brings together representatives from across this industry. This year's seminar began yesterday and is being attended by 200 aviation safety specialists from all areas of the industry. The seminar will permit exchange and discussion on ways to improve air safety. In fact, this year's theme is: Maintaining aviation safety in an era of declining revenues.
April 2, 1992

The number of safety officers has also been increased and additional modules have been provided for the successful Company Aviation Safety Program and Pilot Decision Making Program which were created in response to client-industry demand. As regulators ensuring aviation safety, Transport Canada has made far reaching changes within the industry and has been responsive and responsible to the recommendations of the commission of inquiry.
On the critical issue of de-icing in general and in particular related safety measures, Transport Canada has acted quickly and positively. The department has made clear its commitment to ensuring that the Canadian aviation industry is as informed and diligent as it can be in this crucial area of performance.
I believe that Transport Canada is fully able to provide the Canadian traveller with one of the safest and most efficient air transportation systems in the world.
In conclusion, the Minister of Transport has stated that he is firmly committed to keeping the public fully informed of all actions and plans in response to the recommendations contained in the final commission of inquiry report. The Minister of Transport will be issuing a progress report in six months' time.
This government has an ongoing commitment to making whatever improvements and adjustments are necessary to ensure that a national aviation system is as safe as it possibly can be.

Mr. Speaker, virtually everything the member who has just spoken has said seems to deny one of the fundamental issues identified by Justice Moshansky after years of investigation, innumerable witnesses and three volumes of report.
What he denies essentially is that a large part of the problem, the risk to safety, arises from a shortage of staff and a shortage of resources. The report is simply riddled with quotes like "excessive workloads", "thrown to the wolves without adequate training", "experienced inspectors leaving because they are not being adequately paid".
We have a series of eight different reports saying that we do not have the resources. We do not have the people to carry out the mandate of the Transport Department.
Supply
We need new resources. We need more people. We need better training.
We have in some areas related directly to safety an increase in workload of 400 times. I think it is important to quote directly from the transcript of the hearings. When an official raised the problem of shortage of staff to cany out the regulations and to carry out the mandate for public safety, the commissioner inquired: "What response were you getting from your superiors?" "Other than losing a person-year, no response". "What were the reasons? What was your understanding?" Answer: "We were downsizing." "You were what? You were downsizing?" "Downsizing." "In staff?" "Yes, Sir". "In effect, you were asking for more inspectors, but in fact, they were taking inspector positions away from you." "Yes".
"What about your workload? Were they reallocating your workload or requesting you to do less work?" "No." "What was happening?" "We were being asked to do more with less."
That is the litany of this government, in Health and Welfare Canada, in marine safety, in ground safety throughout the Department of Transport, in customs inspections, in the inspection of new chemicals in agriculture, in the inspection of new drugs.
I ask the hon. member who with me has spent the last few weeks looking at the future health of the Public Service, will his government admit the essential problem here is lack of personnel to carry out the directions and the laws of Parliament? Will he read this report? Will he admit that? Can we hear something other than denial of the fundamental problem here?

Mr. Speaker, I have to go back to my opening statement in my presentation that Canada is among the best in the world for safety records.
I stated the number of aircraft inspectors has increased and air worthiness staff has increased by some 6 per cent and 4 per cent respectively over the years. I do not think the member is saying that because there is a vacancy let us immediately fill it with a warm body. There is an expectation from not only parliamentarians but also from passengers and people in the industry that a professional level of service has to be provided.

April 2, 1992

Again, hon. members opposite say that the government has not responded in a comprehensive way to the work of the inquiry. I mentioned earlier the recommendations of the interim report. We have seen some 49 per cent of the recommendations in this report responded to.
The thing we are discovering not only with Transport Canada but also in the bill that the hon. member and I are spending a lot of time on now is that we are talking about a partnership, working together and everyone has to share in those responsibilities. We are progressing in the right direction.
Whether we are talking about the Public Service or about air transportation safety, the Canadian record is among the best in the world. We all acknowledge that we want to improve on being the best. We will continue to operate in that direction.

Mr. Speaker, I listened veiy carefully to the hon. member's speech. Although he says that perhaps we should not fill a position right away, is he aware of the very huge increase in movement in the air of the very large numbers of smaller planes and that would require a lot more personnel to inspect each and every one of them?
Is the hon. member saying that a very small increase in the personnel is capable of keeping these aircraft in top condition and of making sure that everything is running properly?
I give an example. For Sudbury, Ontario, there was an increase of 171 per cent in the numbers of turbo-planes flying in and out of Sudbury. That is a very large increase in numbers of flights. Even though it is a smaller plane, there are more of them to keep that steady level of traffic going. We cannot service that large number of planes with the same number of personnel. I ask the hon. member, does he think we can?

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the question from the hon. member for Sudbury. The question is related in a generic sense to the number of planes. If we were dealing in 1920 where it is a manpower issue, I would have to agree with the member.
However, this is the 1990s. I just did a tour out west where it is now computer assisted to help with the volumes of work that air traffic controllers must handle.
Inspection techniques have improved. The equipment that professionals have has improved.
The member is quite right. I do not doubt her numbers about the increased number of movements in the air. I know that my colleague from Hamilton will also agree that indeed the professionalism and the quality of the inspectors' work is enhanced by the equipment they have. They recognize that. That is why we have added as we get the trained staff and we are just not going to fill it up with warm bodies.
I just want to assure the members that this government will not and has not compromised safety.
I would also like to remind the hon. members opposite that Judge Moshansky's assessment about the safety of our system today was that it was one of the safest aviation systems in the world.

Madam Speaker, I am more than anxious to participate in the debate today. Just to remind the House, the debate today is on an opposition day motion. It reads:
That this House condemns the government for its unwillingness to concede that the deregulation of the Canadian transport industry has been a failure and in fact has led to fewer carriers, fewer jobs, higher prices, reduced service and less safe operations in air, road and rail transportation.
Canadians who are following the debate today and in particular who have followed the speeches of members on the government side of the House have to realize that this is an important debate. What is important and what is frightening about the debate is that nothing has changed in seven or eight years.
A great many members in the House today have been here since the 1988 election; some came after the 1984 election. Some members will recall the debates about deregulation in Canada from first-hand experience and some will not.
Some have done their homework and will realize that the discussion we are having today about safety in the airline industry, as great a report as the Moshansky report is on the Dryden crash, does not flow, does not find its beginning, does not originate with the Moshansky report. The millions of dollars, the thousands of hours of testimony that gave rise to the Moshansky report do not contain within them the origin of the discussion in Canada and in this House about safety in the airline industry.
April 2, 1992

I had the privilege, as did other members of this Etouse, of being a transport critic once upon a time for my party. At first I was an associate transport critic and then the transport critic when deregulation of the airline industry took place.
I can tell you, Madam Speaker, and you will recall because you were here in those years, that there was a heck of a debate, both in the Standing Committee on Transport, on the floor of the House of Commons and in the forum of Question Period about safety.
With all due respect to Judge Moshansky, there is absolutely almost nothing in this report that was not raised by members of the opposition, by members of the Canadian Airline Pilots Association, by members of the Canadian Air Traffic Controllers Association, by personnel from Transport Canada and the safety division who came and pleaded with members of Parliament in all parties to recognize the dangers inherent in deregulating an industry, to recognize the requirement to prepare in advance for deregulation.
My colleague from Hamilton West who is now associate transport critic has given me a copy of a question on December 17, 1985 I asked the then Minister of Transport, the gentleman who is currently Deputy Prime Minister. I was joined by the members for Regina- Lumsden, Thunder Bay-Atikokan, Papineau-Saint-Michel, and many others who were asking the then Minister of Transport whether or not safety would be compromised. The Minister of Transport of the day said: "Don't worry about it. We are not deregulating safety, we are only deregulating transportation".
I recall that we asked the minister of the day whether or not he would send the Standing Committee on Transport and the appropriate critics to Washington to examine the United States experience with deregulation. They had been there, seven or eight years along at that point in the game. They had learned some lessons. We suggested that perhaps we could learn from them. What was their experience, what did they do right, what did they do wrong, what was the experience? The government refused to send us to Washington to examine the U.S. experience with deregulation.

So, a couple of us went on a Canada-U.S. exchange to Washington and we went to the FAA. We saw the transportation secretary and saw members of Congress associated with the congressional oversight committees responsible for transportation deregulation. We met with vice-presidents and presidents of various airlines operating in the United States in a deregulated environment. That was all done unofficially. We came back to Canada and reported on the U.S. experience.
I have in my hand a copy of the Debates in the House of Commons dated January 29, 1986, when we reported to the government. They were not the views of the Liberal Party or the NDP or the union or the air traffic controllers or the pilots association. They were the views of Congress, of the Federal Aviation Administration, of senior executives of the U.S. airline industry that deregulation in the United States had been brought about without proper preparation.
They warned us then, in 1986, that the single most important thing we had to do was train sufficient air traffic controllers and put in place sufficient inspectors to keep the industry safe. That is what they told us and that is what we reported to the government.
Even then as we reported to the government that information from south of the border, this government was laying off air traffic controllers at Pearson International Airport.
So, I am sorry. I do not feel very generous today in participating in this debate. I do not accept the bland assurances, typewritten, drafted, crafted by somebody else for the member opposite by some bureaucrat that all is well in the world. "We can be assured this government would never compromise safety." That is what the government told us in 1985. That is what the government told us in 1986. That is what the government answered when we came back from Washington in 1986, that this government would never compromise safety.
But the same government, including the member on the backbench who just spoke, told us that the government would never compromise safety, would never put the lives and limbs of Canadians at risk, in the words of Justice Moshansky in a royal commission report, bought and paid for with taxpayer dollars which cannot be

April 2, 1992

written off, ignored and pretended it never happened, judged harshly this government.
It was not Brian Tobin from Humber-St. Barbe- Baie Verte, not an NDP opposition critic, not a union member, not a member of the Canadian Airline Pilots Association, not an air traffic controller, not a concerned citizen. Justice Moshansky said that is exactly what the government did. The government compromised safety.
The government was saying in the House of Commons in answer to me in 1985, it answered to me and to others in 1986 that safety was not compromised. That was the answer up front. Even as it gave those commitments up front in this House, it was back in the shop laying off air traffic controllers. That is the fact.
Nothing has changed. We still get a statement today from the minister, not from an opposition member, not a union member, not a reporter, not a journalist. The minister rejects Justice Moshansky. He dismisses it like the snow in spring. It melts away in front of him, all of the hours of work, all of the blood, sweat and tears and testimony of all of those involved, including some survivors of the crash. It is rejected out of hand.
You rejected it.

We did not compromise safety. And the member opposite blindly stands up and says: "We have never compromised safety".
I never rejected Justice Moshansky's report. The member should be very clear. The member should take this matter seriously. What I said was that we did not need to wait for a crash. We did not need to wait for the loss of lives. We did not need to wait for a royal commission to act. In 1986, well in advance of the report of 1992, those questions were being raised and false assurances were being given. No action was taken.
I say to members opposite that this is a serious matter. I say to members opposite that there is no tangible indication that anything has substantively changed. That is what Justice Moshansky tells us as well.
Take the airline industry, for example. Today two carriers are engaged, and we may as well call it exactly what it is, in a corporate fight to the death. These two Canadian carriers, let us be honest, are in a corporate fight to the death. All of the seat sales, all of the
promotions, all of the little chances to win a bonus, an executive upgrade, a free trip, a free holiday, all of these promotions are part of a corporate fight to the death. Two Canadian carriers have decided that by competitive means only one carrier shall survive. That is what is going on today. As part and parcel of that corporate battle, both carriers are looking at the possibility of finding new American partners, a minority sharehold position that can only go, by law, up to 25 per cent as prescribed in the National Transportation Act, but could result in control.
It is against that backdrop and that environment of a corporate war, the possibility of mergers with American carriers and frankly, with an American corporate culture, that we are having this debate.
I do not care who hears me. I have no hesitation in saying that the Canadian airline industry today, in my judgment, and the corporate culture that engenders the industry today is far superior to the corporate culture that engenders the American industry. The American industry has been floating in debt for so long that it is no longer run by airline industry people. It has been run by the bankers for a heck of a long time. In the United States, they are operating just at the margins provided by the FAA.
It used to be the American industry. If we can picture an invisible line here that is the limit below which you cannot go in terms of safety margins. The American industry used to operate up here, but as deregulation came in, the industry began to operate right at the margin, right at the lowest allowable limit. That is what happened. That is the experience south of the border.
What happened in Canada as well is that we also began moving down toward the safety margin. The trick in any industry is not to operate at the lowest minimum standard. It is to be above it. For every degree you are above it, that is an assurance that you are operating safely. That was the traditional culture in the airline industry. That culture has changed. It is not airline people anymore determining when you push off the gate and take off. It is the banks because they own the carriers. It is because they are awash in debt south of the border and they are awash in debt here in Canada as well.
April 2, 1992

The corporate pressure, the competitive pressures, the deregulated environment that gave rise to the tragedy at Dryden, which gave rise to this report has not lessened; it has increased. The need to make the industry safe is greater now than it was four or five years ago.
You can only begin to deal with the problem when you first recognize that one exists. What is frightening today is to see the government continue to say in a rather bland fashion, no substance whatsoever: "It is safe. You can trust me. We would never allow the industry to operate in a risky fashion".
I accept that no human being consciously-not one on that side of the House, not one minister, not one member-puts another human being at risk. I accept that. I do not believe there is one member over there who would do that consciously. But I recognize as well that if members opposite find themselves on their knees before an ideology, before the altar of so-called unfettered capitalism, if they get blinded by this notion that totally unshackled, unregulated enterprise always provides the best level of service to our society, that in their adoration before that ideology they have lost sight of the need to serve people.
When you judge what has happened with deregulation in Canada against what was promised as the benefits, deregulation has indeed failed. What were we promised? We were promised we would have a more competitive airline industry. Before deregulation came out, let me remind members, we had EPA as an eastern carrier, we had a Quebec-based carrier, we had Air Ontario as an Ontario-based secondary regional carrier, we had a whole variety starting out with Air B.C. Northwest Territories had their own Northwest Air. There was a whole variety of regional carriers all across Canada, some of which had agreements in terms of marketing, in terms of delivering passengers to and fro, in terms of sharing various services at airports. We had a whole variety of regional carriers, all aspiring to expand their base in a partially regulated environment. There were two major carriers, Air Canada and CP, going at it.
What happened after deregulation? Did we get more competition as promised? We ended up with every single
Supply
one of the regional carriers being swallowed up and aligned either with Canadian or Air Canada. Wardair disappeared. EPA disappeared. Quebec Air disappeared. All of these regional small carriers as independent entities disappeared and we ended up with a duopoly in Canada. We ended up with a lot less competition.
We were promised lower air fares. Now there is one for those people who live on the fringe of the country, lower air fares. If you live in a competitive market, such as flying between Toronto and Miami, I suppose you might have got a lower air fare out of deregulation. But if you live where I was last week in Rankin Inlet, you did not get lower air fares. You got practically a prison term in terms of your economic ability to be able to fly in and out of your community.
If you live, as I do, in the area I represent in western Newfoundland, in Deer Lake, if you live in Goose Bay, Prince Rupert, Prince George, Smithers, Prince Albert, if you live in what was known as Chimo in northern Quebec, or Iqaluit in Northwest Territories, northern Ontario, Regina or Saskatoon-let us get some bigger cities in here-check out the air fares. They have not gone down. They have dramatically gone up.
It used to be that we took the high-volume routes in this country. Because we licensed carriers on the basis of the stops they made, which they were compelled to make and we subsidized the far-flung regions somewhat, we cross-subsidized them from the high-volume routes. That is what we did. We gave the people who lived in the smaller centres somewhat of a break by cross-subsidizing under the heavy volume routes.
What have we done now? We have done just the opposite. Now we make people who are captive, served by only one carrier, pay whatever the airline charges. So it cost $2,000 to fly to Rankin Inlet from Ottawa and back.
Then we use the big seat sales in Ottawa between Ottawa and Florida and we cross-subsidize those with the people who live in Rankin Inlet. The ones who are captive living in the small communities pay whatever they are charged. In effect they are subsidizing people to go on holiday in Florida. That is the new corporate culture that has grabbed Canada. On the question of lower fares this is not a success. Safety, hardly a success.

April 2, 1992
