Canada is not the United States. Canada has a larger land mass. We forget that huge land mass called Yukon and Northwest Territories. It is a relatively small population, less than a tenth of the United States. There are a number of things that have bound us together historically for 125 years. This is the 125th year. What are they? The post office and its little flag flying in the smallest most remote community was a symbol of our nationhood. The flag. There were some fundamental social programs, the ability to communicate with each other with telecommunications and a reasonable level of transportation, originally bands of steel from sea to sea on the railway. In latter days, the airlines allowed us, despite our vast differences and distances, to communicate with each other, to share with each other and to celebrate that diversity.
Why start withdrawing those things this year? In a few weeks Air Canada is sponsoring, with the support of the government, the opposition, the Speaker and all members of Parliament, an exchange. There will be 125 young people from every district in Canada going to another district to talk to each other because we recognize the country is hurting and we have to bring people together. Therefore, we have a special program to bring people together. We do it this year as part of the 125-year celebration of Confederation. Why would a country say it is important to do that as a special initiative, but yet in its transportation policy make that impossible in every day life?
Madam Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity for an extra minute to conclude.
I will conclude by saying to the extent that deregulation has severed one of the links that has traditionally kept this country together, to the extent that we now recognize through special initiatives that we need to reopen those links, we have to look at deregulation. We have to look at a measure of re-regulation. We have to begin to put back together the bonds that used to bind this country together. One of them is transportation. We have to undo this hastily organized deregulation that has not only put our industry at risk in terms of safety, but put our country at risk in terms of our ability to speak with and to each other.

Madam Speaker, it is a pleasure to listen to the debate today. I think some very fundamental points, not only about transportation and deregulation, but about the nature of the country are being made in this debate. I think it
behoves the government of the day to listen very carefully to what is being said here.
In my maiden speech in this House in December 1988, I pointed out that having looked at the geographic area of representation, it turned out that 83 per cent of the geographic area of this country is represented by the opposition and only 17 per cent of the geographic area of this country is represented by the government. Obviously, square miles do not vote, nor do the trees or whatever.
That made it very clear to me that the whole direction the government had been on, freedom to move, free trade and so on, was seen by the regions of this country as something that was operating totally contrary to their interests and their future. We have seen this trend accelerate over the period of time I have been in this House.
If we look at government program after government program, how the government funds regional development, how it develops transportation policy, VIA Rail and so on, the post office, it is a kick to the regions of this country. If people are wondering why there is discontent in the land and why people are feeling disconnected from their country, it is precisely because of policies like those.
I would like to ask the hon. member if he sees the same scope to the dimension of what we are talking about as well?

Madam Speaker, I thank the member for his question. I must say that I think he has given all of us something to think about. I certainly was not aware that 83 per cent of the land mass of the country is represented by opposition members and 17 per cent of the land mass is represented by government members.
Perhaps that helps us understand better why post offices have disappeared from rural Canada. Perhaps that helps us understand better why VIA Rail has disappeared from the smaller stations in this country. Perhaps that helps us understand better why some airports have not only lost jet service, but some have totally lost all service in the smaller parts of this country. Perhaps that helps us understand why the railway has not just declined but has disappeared in some parts of this country, P.E.I. and Newfoundland totally and many other branch lines across this country. Perhaps that helps us understand why in 1992 people look to their provincial premiers to be their spokespersons and no longer look, regrettably, to their national parliament.
April 2, 1992

Perhaps that helps us understand why people in Canada today define themselves politically by whom they are against rather than by whom they are for and define themselves philosophically by what they oppose rather than what they support. We have appealed to the negative, frustrated, angry, disenfranchised, left-out, shut-out side of our character and we have forgotten to appeal to what binds us together in this country.
I could not agree with the member more. This is not merely a matter of dollars and cents. It is a question of nation building. It is a question as to whether or not people believe at the end of the day that by virtue of citizenship there are certain things we hold in common. There are lots of thing that make us different no matter where we come from. Some of us have mountains. Some of us have prairies. Some have water and some have droughts. Some speak one language and some another. Some have booming economies and some have seasonal economies. Lots of things make us different but there are only a few things we hold in common no matter where we live. That is what pulls us together: our sense of values.
When the member says that the withdrawal of transportation services is one of those values we held in common, one of those things we thought defined us as being a Canadian no matter where we lived, no matter what our circumstance, what our language, he is absolutely right. That is the message I tried to bring to this House as often as I could. That is the message I think this government lost sight of in the pursuit of the bottom line and as it knelt before the altar of its right wing philosophy. I do not think it did it deliberately. I do not think it was by design. I do not think it was entirely by accident. It really failed to see, as the member pointed out, or perhaps forgot about 83 per cent of the land mass of the country not represented by members on that side of the House.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: I understand that the hon. member for Elk Island will be sharing his time.

Madam Speaker, I wish to speak in response to the hon. member's motion that the government's economic regulatory reform of
Supply
the transportation industry has been a failure. What fiction indeed. I not only take exception to this claim but find its tenor and argument to be somewhat wanting if not totally preposterous.
Since 1985 this government has taken a number of steps and many a hard decision to ensure that Canadian transportation industries could flourish in a more economically competitive and unfettered climate, liberated as it were from undue government hindrance and given the freedom to move to pursue new heights limited only by the powers of imagination, vigour and their determination.
This environment for change was not brought about by self-serving purposes. Rather it seems to benefit all who would use or rely on transportation for reasons of trade and commerce as well as personal travel or pleasure. Moreover, as business and transportation in Canada are inextricably linked and on the move, this government is scarcely going to embark on a course of action that would thwart one form of success for another.
It is precisely about success that I wish to focus my remarks today as exemplified by VIA Rail Canada, working proof of the railroad maxim: "The little engine that could". Part of the problem with VIA Rail in the late 1970s and in the 1980s was the heavy degree of government intervention in the transportation marketplace. This occurred through direct rail passenger subsidies of about 75 per cent of the cost of services. This meant some inequities for the air mode which was subsidized at a lesser level and indirectly through provision of infrastructure. It meant major inequities for the bus mode which received virtually no direct government subsidies. Moreover, the bus mode was in direct competition with a heavily subsidized VIA Rail on a number of comparable routes.
The heavy government subsidies, as well as the denial of a level playing field, offered VIA Rail no incentives to modernize or innovate, knowing that the government would pay whatever deficits occurred in passenger rail services.
Looking back, the soothsayers of doom and gloom who prophesized the inevitable fall of the sky in 1989 as a result of streamlining VIA Rail are doubtless practising their art of "poultry predictions" elsewhere today.

April 2, 1992
Supply
What remains is a leaner, more efficient and professional national passenger railway company, not to mention that awful word successful which my hon. friend fears and despises. That is not a bad record when we consider the few options the Minister of Transport had back then. Tough times required tough decisions.
This government did not abdicate its responsibility to act, nor was it afraid to take tough decisions. Instead it chose to save VIA by imbuing it with new life, mindful of considerable public cynicism and very much aware of a resurgence in passenger rail travel throughout the world replete with its safety, social and environmental benefits.
Not only does VTA's future look bright on several financial and performance score cards, but VIA is also planning with a view to the future. Once again I would say to my hon. friend that when it comes time to peek into the future much has changed since the days of Mackenzie King and the corresponding practices of the arts and wizardry.
The realities of 1990, however, are proof that the new VIA cannot only operate within the limits of available funding but can do so at even less the anticipated cost to government, and in spite of the current downturn in travel for business or leisure.
As hon. members know, VIA has been operating some 396 trains per week over 19 routes since the change took effect in January 1990. While these frequencies are down from previous levels of operation, VIA still continues to serve Canadians in all regions of the country, including several remote regions where passenger rail service is presently the only link to the outside world.
In addition, VIA has faced and survived stiff competition from the lucrative and heavily travelled airline routes in central Canada, particularly those along the Quebec City-Windsor corridor. Thus what began as an exercise to streamline certain services has ultimately resulted in today's VIA, a trend setting network operating at less expense to the taxpayer, meeting today's needs, and keeping its eye on the future.
Indeed, the newly structured VIA was deliberately focused to rethink the conduct of business for passenger rail not only within funding levels set by the federal
government but, more important, to meet the challenges of increasing its passenger volume while operating in the mode of a cost effective enterprise. At the risk of sounding repetitive, VIA has been successful on both counts.
Much of this success is due in large part to VIA's own awareness of its product, image and service to the travelling public. That is to say the new consumer credo of the nineties, "service, service, service" is not lost on VIA's executive, marketing staff, or on-train personnel. Once on board this mantra becomes innovative: do more and better with corporate pride and the client in mind. Over a year has come and gone since the so-called cataclysmic collapse of VIA and it is still operating stronger than ever.
On December 16, 1991 VIA announced major increases in the frequency of service in the Montreal-Ot-tawa-Toronto triangle based on traffic patterns and demand. Some 22 new trains a week were added into service offering more flexible itineraries, better connections, and more opportunities for same day return travel between these cities.
One month later VIA chairman Lawrence Hanigan released a year-end report and traffic studies confirming increased ridership by 5 per cent over 1990 with revenues up by 7 per cent. With less direct subsidies, VIA was able to operate the network for $8.5 million less than originally budgeted in 1991 and by $38 million less than required from the previous year. This has all been accomplished with the use of better equipment, improved productivity, and the quality of on-board services.
Instead of abandoning transportation industries in Canada, I am pleased to report that this government has spent over $4 billion in direct operating assistance to VIA since 1984, helping the railway to move some 46 million passengers in that same period of time.
Figures such as these and a renaissance in train travel and service since VIA's newly streamlined network came into place do not qualify for, much less deserve, the unfounded and odious criticism of abandonment and neglect. Such is the woeful lament of the ill-informed and not worthy of my hon. friend, unless I misjudge him and his service to this House.
April 2, 1992

In closing, I would just like to borrow two little words often heard in VIA stations as my greeting to the hon. member or anyone else with fixed negative mindsets when it comes to staring reality in the face of success: all aboard.

speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I take pleasure in being able to participate in the debate of the following opposition day motion:
That this House condemns the government for its unwillingness to concede that the deregulation of the Canadian transport industry has been a failure and in fact has led to fewer carriers, fewer jobs, higher prices, reduced service and less safe operations in air, road and rail transportation.
The problem with this motion, as so often is the case, is that it is stated in the extreme. It is not that there are not some problems in the transportation industry in Canada. It is not that we do not have to do some things to repair some of the areas and improve some of the areas. However, to have a motion that says it has been a failure is absurdity.
Obviously the person who has written this motion has not lived in the regions that have seen improved service as a result of deregulation. The motion reads "fewer carriers". Madam 'Speaker, if you were living in an outlying community 200 miles from one of the metropolitan areas and you had a choice between jet service once a day and you had to wait all day for that jet in the evening or early in the morning and be gone all day, and two or three or four turbo-prop services that same day and a choice among those carriers, which would you take?
To say that there are fewer carriers is an absurdity. All you have to do is look at the back of the airline magazine as you fly to work here to see the network of airline points that were not there a few years ago and to know that deregulation has provided more service to the communities. It just is not accurate to have this kind of a statement.
Then it goes on to say "fewer jobs". I remember machinists from the airline coming to me a few years ago saying: "Please do not support deregulation. We will lose jobs if you do that". Even logic without statistics shows
Supply
that that is wrong because if there are more carriers there are going to be more jobs.
I noticed that just about a year ago in the province of British Columbia they announced there was a shortage of maintenance people in the airline industry. They wanted people to come and train in airline sheet metal work. They needed that kind of worker.
I am not saying that in other areas of the transport industry there has not been a reduction in jobs. There has been a reduction in jobs in the wood working industry. The logging industry used to hire two or three times as many people to work as it does now. There has been a reduction in jobs. In the chicken industry we used to have people shovelling out the bams and gathering eggs. It is done on conveyers now. There have been job losses in every major industry that wants to upgrade its technology.
To pick on deregulation as a sign of job loss makes the motion unbelievable. To say that there are "higher prices" and assign that to deregulation, I think everyone will concede that if you have competition you reduce prices. If one airline is competing against another airline for passenger service, or a trucker is competing against another tracker for passenger service, there is going to be a reduction in price.
I can take the member back to the days when it was regulated. I ask him to look at any financial page where the profits of companies are announced and compare the profits of companies on the free market system with those companies that are regulated by a utility commission to see which one has the higher profits. He will see Quaker Oats might have 3 or 4 per cent but the gas company regulated by the government will have 7, 8 or 9 per cent. Uniformly those that go through a public utilities commission, those commissioners always make sure that the monopoly has a better write-up of profits than the competition. To say that there are higher prices may be the case but not because of deregulation.
How about reduced service because of deregulation? I have not seen it. It would be a useful motion to debate the value of deregulation but to say that it has been a failure just cannot be supported by evidence. The motion says "less safe". The Minister of Transport mentioned in the House the other day that there are fewer accidents now per air mile than there have been in history.

April 2, 1992
Supply
Competition creates better service, better prices and better jobs. If you look at any other industry that depends on the transport industry you will know that is the fact. There are problems now. Canada has, I think, severe transportation problems but they are not problems of deregulation.
We have a problem of critical mass of population. To have a transportation industry that functions efficiently so that it can enjoy the kind of profits it needs to upgrade its equipment and so forth, we need 50 million to 60 million people. Canada does not have that critical mass in order to enjoy that kind of efficiency.
Second, the metropolitan areas where the profits are to be made are scattered and there are not the many centres close together as there are in Europe, for example, or in the United States where you have huge population centres close to each other and they can be connected more easily by rapid transit. We do have geographical problems and they make it more difficult for the transportation industry to function.
We have done some things. We have reduced taxes. If members will remember the budget of just a month ago, the capital cost allowance was reduced so that the trucking industry can function more competitively, so that the airline industry, buying equipment, can function more competitively and so the buses can do that. The cost of operation, when you can write down those costs more quickly, helps them to compete.
A lot has been done. I remember when I first campaigned to come into this House, a seasoned politician statesman in the lower mainland of B.C. was campaigning with me and he said to me: "You know, I don't know why you are doing it. Back there in Ottawa they are not going to listen to you anyway". The major problem for British Columbia was freight rates. My friend from Nanaimo remembers that. Raw materials could be brought from the west to central Canada but to bring finished products from the west into central Canada cost a lot more in order to enhance the industrial complex in central Canada.
One of the first things we did as a government was to take that disadvantage away so that the manufacturing industry in British Columbia at least would not be facing the disadvantage of a built-in bias against western industry and I am proud of that. It was because western members came to Ottawa and said: "We need freedom for movement. The industries in British Columbia deserve just as much a chance to operate competitively as those in central Canada". We levelled off the playing field in terms of the freight rates.
We still have the disadvantage of distance and the disadvantage of large metropolitan areas and it still costs a lot to bring finished products in in the quantity we need to make it as competitive as we would like to be, but we have taken a government-induced impediment out of the way and that is deregulation.
My friend from central Canada laughs. We are used to that. People from the great golden triangle here do not know what it is like to operate a business in western Canada and have freight rates that are prejudiced against you. They think that is the way it ought to be, bring your raw materials to Ontario, bring the finished products to the west. Finally, a few years ago we levelled it and made it more equitable for the people in the west.
I say that the motion, which is designed to ask us to examine freight rates and deregulation would be a useful motion if it were not so extreme, if it did not say it so dramatically.
Do we need to examine it? There are areas we need to examine, but to say it has been a failure when VIA Rail passenger service is up, when it is functioning, as my friend from Edmonton said just a few minutes ago. When we worked with VIA Rail two years ago, the doomsayers across the way were saying: "This is the end of Canada" and now we find that passenger service is up and they are telling us that deregulation is a failure.
Every time you introduce competition, you introduce the opportunity for success.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
I would like to designate tomorrow as an allotted day,
April 2, 1992
The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. Angus (p. 9219).

Madam Speaker, without getting into too much partisanship,
I want to mention to the hon. member the effects of deregulation in my riding of Restigouche-Chaleur. We have an airport at Charlo, New Brunswick. It is a Transport Canada airport and it is managed by an effective and competent board of directors representing the municipalities of Dalhousie, Charlo and Campbell-ton.
Here are the facts. In the 1980s two airlines served that airport. One had jet service, the other had turboprop. We now have one turbo-prop airline. We had a weather station but it was closed by the federal government. We have a flight service station in existence right now, but that has been targeted for closure and unless the Minister of Transport designates it in some way, it will not stay open.
My concern, and the member did not address it that much, is the cost recovery. He talked about regions and about a level playing field for the west, and the east I suppose in the same breath, but how about that cost recovery? That is going to hurt the regions. For instance, the same type of plane, a turbo-prop, landing at the Charlo airport in New Brunswick would pay a higher landing fee than the same plane landing in Toronto. I say to the hon. member that is not a fair way of solving that problem.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I noted with care that the member said at one time there was jet service and turbo-prop service and now there is only one turbo-prop service.
I would like to ask him, does he suggest that under a regulated industry, both should be kept alive by government regulation? Since the economic engine for that region has reduced it to only one turbo-prop service, presumably the additional service that used to exist must have been empty. It certainly is not a profitable picture. Would the member suggest that if the service is not needed, that government regulations should keep it going at the taxpayer's expense?
Supply
I want to quote from the Moshansky report of two weeks ago. He says:
I want to re-emphasize that what was deregulated was the economic burden on the industry.
That is exactly what my friend across the way has just illustrated. When you have two services and you need only one, you create an economic burden. The member wants to maintain that kind of service, even though the people are not using it and even though it is going to be a tax burden.
Judge Moshansky went on to say:
The safety regulations have remained in place and indeed have been strengthened over time.
The motion says that safety has been reduced. The most recent report, the Moshansky report, says just the opposite.

Madam Speaker, I do not want to cut into the time of the following speaker, but I would like to ask the member who has just spoken, a question.
He talked about the implications for western Canada. What he said might well be true for the metropolitan centres, as I pointed out in a previous intervention, but could the member describe to me how the deregulation has benefited his former home town of Rosthem, Saskatchewan and what in fact the impact has been due to deregulation? Where are they seeing the new opportunities as a result of the policies the member now extols?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
In answer to my friend from Prince Albert, I will tell you what I will do. I am going to Rosthem in three weeks' time. I am going there for a fund-raiser to help defeat the member in the next election and I will ask the good folks of Rosthem.
But I do know this. They have a beautiful highway that did not exist when I was last there which runs straight through from Saskatoon to Prince Albert. It was not there when I lived there in the good old days. They have a kind of service and can get to Saskatoon from Rosthem in a matter of 30 minutes. You could not do that before on the old gravel highway.

Madam Speaker, in the few minutes remaining in the debate I want to concentrate on the last words in this motion that have to do with reduced service and less safe operations in air, road and rail transportation.

April 2, 1992
Private Members' Business
People out there listening and watching this debate do not have to take my word for it or the word of the member for Hamilton West or any of the opposition members as to why the Diyden air crash happened, and why other factors affecting the safety of the travelling public continue to fail to ensure that Canadians can be assured they are getting the best possible service and the full enforcement of regulations and laws that are designed to protect them.
The report of Judge Moshansky says it all. No matter how often members opposite deny or pretend everything is all right, this report makes it clear that over nearly eight years there were repeated warnings within Transport Canada that there simply were not enough resources to ensure the safety of the travelling public.
There was an A-base review in 1984 and the establishment of a program control board. The Canadian Airline Pilots Association in 1985 issued warnings about deregulation and the impact on safety. In March 1985 the Auditor General had similar cautions about not enough resources.
The Nielsen task force, the work of the greatest hatchet man of all times, recommended an immediate increase in resources to preserve the ability of the department to enforce regulations to ensure safety. In late 1985 we had an official of Transport Canada visiting the United States reviewing the American experience on deregulation.
Literally everything that has happened since then, the reduction in inspections, sending untrained and unqualified inspectors out into the field, everything that has reduced the regulatory assurance that Canadians are entitled to could have been forecast through the crystal ball of the American experience after it deregulated.
In May 1986 the report Aviation Safety In a Changing Environment said the same thing.
In 1989 my colleague raised the issues of safety and staff resources in the House of Commons and so did I. In 1990 we did it again.
The government is continuing to refuse to recognize that if you pass laws, if you adopt new policies that increase the workload dramatically, unless you are prepared to jeopardize the safety of the public you have to be prepared to provide the resources to ensure that your regulations and policies work.
We had a clear conflict between two government policies that the government blindly has refused to recognize for well over seven years. One is deregulation, where there is more work to be done, up to 400 times as much in the case of inspecting aircraft, and at the same time downsizing, more work and less people to do it.
We have the same thing in the marine services within Transport Canada. We have a report that is now over a year old that states there are inadequate resources in marine services to respond to emergencies on the waterways. We have similar warnings in the same reports, which the government ignored for years and years, that land transportation safety is also declining.
Throughout government departments-this is why I raise this so urgently, even with so little time to do so-diminution of resources, lack of training and the loss of highly qualified people are jeopardizing the health and safety of Canadians.
I call on the government to look at the impact, department by department, that its downsizing program has had. Look at how many regulations and laws of this Parliament are not being implemented for protection and safety, simply because the government has refused to provide the resources.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
Unfortunately I must interrupt the hon. member.

It being 6 p.m., it is my duty to inform the House that pursuant to Standing Order 81(17), the proceedings on the motion have expired.

Pursuant to Standing Order 30(7) the House will now proceed to the consideration of Private Members' Business as listed on today's Order Paper.
April 2, 1992

That, in the opinion of this House, the government should enact appropriate legislation to guarantee the political rights of public employees.
He said: Madam Speaker, in moving this motion, I want to refer to the legislation as it now exists, specifically to section 33, which reads in part:
33(1) Except as authorized under this section, no employee shall
(a)	Engage in work for or against a candidate and
(b)	Engage in work for or against a political party or;
(c)	Be a candidate.
Section 32 defines the word candidate. It reads:
A "candidate" means a candidate for election as a member of the House of Commons, a member of the legislature of a province or a member of the Council of the Yukon Territory or the Northwest Territories.
It does not go any further in defining candidate than the words I have read. It leaves me open to wonder whether a candidate is a candidate when that person declares himself to be one or is possibly nominated by a group of those qualified to vote in that election, as is done by political parties. Or does a person become a candidate on the day that they are officially nominated before the returning officer?
When it reads "to campaign for it", it must mean for the whole period, from the time a person indicates his desire to become a candidate and then becomes one by whatever procedure he or she uses. From that point on that person is a candidate. That means that no person in the Public Service could do that, but there are exceptions.
In subsection 2 a person does not contravene subsection 1 simply by contributing money to the person who is running or to a political party. Again, it is vague in that it does not say whether a person can join a party. I know in the past it has been interpreted to mean just exactly that, that while you might make a donation you cannot be a member of a political party if you are a public servant.
There is a further exception in subsection 3: "Notwithstanding any other act, the Public Service Commission may grant to an employee leave of absence without pay
Private Members' Business
to seek nomination as a candidate and to be a candidate for election".
Again, that presents difficulty for public servants. In my case, I was first nominated on May 1 for the election that took place six months and three weeks later, on November 21, 1988. I had been seeking the nomination for the previous 10 months, which means that if I had been a public servant during that period, I would have gone for a period of some 16 months, if my mathematics is reasonably close, without pay.
I would have had to ask for leave of absence. I would have had to depend on the Public Service Commission to give me that leave of absence, and I would have gone without pay for that whole period.
If one knew when the election was coming, one could time it a little better from the point of view of being without pay. If there is anyone who knows that far ahead, it would be only one person, and even the government leader would not know a year or two ahead of time what date the election was going to be.
It does work a considerable hardship against public servants in particular, a hardship that does not exist with respect to anyone else in the community qualified to run. They can run without having to worry about giving up their employment, getting leave of absence or being without pay for that whole time.
It seems to me that a case can be made on those grounds alone for legislation that changes it and gives public servants at least some of the rights of regular, ordinary citizens-I hate using the word ordinary, it is overused with respect to people.
This has been argued over the years and in 1986, I think it was, the trial division of the Federal Court ruled that section 33 was contrary to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. That is the section I read which said you cannot become a candidate, you cannot try to become a candidate, you cannot do all those things unless you are exempted by having had the permission of the Public Service Commission.
They challenged that legislation on the grounds that it was contrary to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms but they lost at that level. They then appealed in 1988 to the Federal Court of Appeal. That court struck down section 33(l)(a) and 33(l)(b). It left in place subsection (c); but it did strike down 33(l)(a) and 33(l)(b) in June 1988.

April 2, 1992
Private Members' Business
The Public Service Commission appealed that decision to the Supreme Court of Canada, and in June 1991 the decision was rendered that confirmed the decision of the Federal Court.
It did strike down subsection 33(1) which stopped you from doing almost anything, engaging in work for or against the candidate, or engaging in work for or against the party. Again, it is interpretation. What is working for a party? I can recall a friend of mine who was a public servant when this happened. Someone reported to his employer that he had a lawn sign in front of his house. He was called up before his supervisor who told him he would have to get that lawn sign down because it was contrary to the legislation. He said that it was his wife's house. The supervisor said: "It may be his wife's house but it was his job that was on the line". He took the sign down.
It seems to me that is certainly going to the extreme in saying the degree of participation that a public servant, any public servant, can engage in at the time of an election.
The Supreme Court ruled that the prohibition of public servants working for or against a candidate or party violated the freedom as expressed in section 2(b) of the charter. However, the court recognized the importance of the political neutrality of the Public Service and of public servants. I think we all agree with that. There has to be some recognition of that.
The court stated that the present provision in banning political activities without distinction and without regard for the nature of the work performed by the public servant in . the Public Service went further than was necessary. It stated further that legislation could be enacted which would limit the political activities of public servants. It gave some indication of how future legislation might be framed in order to achieve the objective of a neutral Public Service.
It is still up to the public servant to define in his own mind and hope that what he is doing is proper. Employees are required to exercise judgment and to consider their specific circumstances, the kind of work that they are doing, the level of their position in the public service and the way in which they are engaging in political activities, particularly with due regard to the loyalty they
owe to the government and to their obligation to act and be seen to act impartially when dealing with the public. None of us would want their political partisan activities to interfere in any way at all with their delivery of a service to the public. I think everyone will agree with that.
With the court decisions, the employees are still bound by section 33(3) of the Public Service Employment Act with respect to seeking candidacy. They still have to get permission. They still have to get leave of absence. They still have to go without pay for the whole time they are campaigning to get a nomination and the time they are running until the election is decided, which could easily be in some cases a couple of years. We do not know when that is going to happen. I presented my own case and said that it would have been in excess of a year had I been a public servant before I would have had any pay.
That does not apply all over Canada. I do not know the situation in other provinces, but in British Columbia a provincial public servant can seek and obtain a nomination without sacrificing anything. He or she can ask for leave of absence without pay for a period of up to 90 days and can choose the time when it is most advantageous to him. In all likelihood that would be the time of the actual election campaign itself and perhaps some time before that, if one could be reasonably sure when the election was coming. At least there is that freedom there. They do not have to ask anyone's permission. Certainly, if they are stepping beyond the bounds of good conduct, then they would be called to task. They do have that much freedom, freedom which, to my mind, goes a long way toward satisfying the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
It is time the federal government approached this legislation, approached its public servants in the same open light with respect to the action of public servants. As long as it does not interfere with their work, they should be allowed to participate as citizens of Canada in the electoral process by supporting a candidate of their choice, by supporting a political party of their choice, by being a candidate if that is their choice, by seeking nomination. Until they actually need time off to participate fully, they should be able to continue with their job and then ask for a leave of absence, unpaid, from the time they feel they have to put all their time into their campaign.
April 2, 1992

I would urge the government and all members of the House to support legislation that would define it so that the people involved would know exactly what the limitations were and the options open to them. All we are asking in this is to make it clear. It is vague now.
We have the legislation, we have the Supreme Court decision and the court suggested legislation could solve the problem. I am urging that the government introduce legislation that will limit the activities to the extent felt necessaty so that people will be fair on both sides, but nevertheless define it so that the public servants engaging in these activities will do so knowing that they are within the bounds of specific legislation.

speakeroldname: Mr. Patrick Boyer (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Defence):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, that was a very thoughtful speech by the member sponsoring the motion before the House on the issue of where one draws the line appropriately on the role that public servants must play necessary to maintain the political neutrality of the Public Service, which at the same time permits public servants to participate in the public life of our country to the extent that they wish to.
I agree with the hon. member that it is important to clearly define this in law because of the certain hiatus that currently exists with the court decision following the review of the existing sections 32 and 33 of the Public Service act that governs this area of political activity by public servants.
When I heard him say he thought that it was important for each individual member of the Public Service "to define in his or her own mind what is appropriate", I felt that was too subjective an approach to be satisfactory either to the Canadian public, the government, or the Public Service itself. That is why again it is important to have this defined in law.
That word in the motion which says that government enact appropriate legislation certainly is the key word: What is appropriate. If you take a historic view of this, the appropriateness certainly changes over the decades and through the centuries.
When I first wrote about this subject over a decade ago in my book called: Political Rights-The Legal Framework
Private Members' Business
of Elections in Canada, I was interested to learn in my research that the efforts to establish the neutrality of the Public Service by de-politicizing it had, in some cases, even gone so far as to remove the right to vote from public servants.
For example, in the pre-Confederation province of Canada, customs and excise workers were disfranchised in 1844. The majority of postal workers lost the right to vote in 1851, and even Crown land agents were denied the right to vote in 1855.
That was perhaps not unconnected with similar tendencies in England at the time when in the years between 1782 and 1866 postal employees and customs and excise officials had also been disfranchised.
Significantly in 1866, when Mr. Gladstone, the great reformer, was bringing in legislation that generally provided for an extension of the franchise in Britain at that time, it included an express provision that would have denied the right to vote to all public servants.
When you look at those kinds of restrictions that applied in the effort to establish a politically neutral Public Service, it is very clear that the whole paradigm within which this current debate is occurring has dramatically shifted.
We are guided particularly by the Charter of Rights and Freedoms which is now a fundamental part of Canadian life setting out the democratic rights that all of us have.
What are the restrictions that are demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society? Most often the quest for increased rights is put in terms of the benefit or the advantage that will accrue to the individual who acquires and can exercise those rights.
I think that seen from the other side of the coin the political restrictions that are by law traditionally imposed on public servants in this country can also be seen as protection for public servants, almost, if you would like, consumer protection legislation for public servants. That is because there are serious implications for those who take a political role in the course of holding a public office or being a member of the Public Service.

April 2, 1992
Private Members' Business
I think the dilemma was perhaps best set out by J.E. Hodgetts, who was certainly one of Canada's leading scholars on public administration. He wrote about this some years back in 1973, almost two decades ago.
In a book on the Canadian Public Service, Hodgetts said the following: "Partisan activity on behalf of the party in power could be interpreted as a form of job insurance for the public servant or his means of ingratiating himself with his political overlords. But at the same time, such activity jeopardized the doctrine of political non-alignment of public servants that protected them against dismissal when a governing party was defeated."
It is important to recognize that in the quest for seeking political liberation for those who occupy positions in the Public Service of our country, there is a problem for the individuals themselves.
I would like to cast that now, even more broadly, in terms of the collective damage that can be done to the Public Service if we do not get this line of demarcation between what is permitted and what is prohibited in the right place.
We all agree that there has to be a line. I think we all agree that it is best expressed in statutory form so that there is certainty for all. The issue here now is just where that line should be.
In a Public Service where hiring and promotion is based on the merit principle, it becomes problematic, very difficult indeed, if the political persuasion of people within the Public Service is known to co-workers, subordinates and superiors.
This country began with a highly politicized Public Service where following each election the rewards of office included the power to dispense public jobs whether it was in the customs office or any other position to those who had been supporters of the successful party at the election.
Indeed, there was a practice. I see the Mace on the Table before us. There was a practice called macing which was the method by which the members were never permitted to walk between the Mace and the Speaker, as the member for Kingston and the Islands knows, but has forgotten in his reference to the Mace, otherwise a persnickety member for parliamentary procedure.
Macing was the extraction by the government of the day of money from public office-holders as a reward for having gotten the position, a 5 per cent levy, an 8 per cent levy of their salary.
Over quite some time this practice was eliminated, but it was only possible as part of the larger effort to establish the Public Service Commission early in this century and to base hiring and promotion on the merit principle.
We have gone through a long struggle in this country to get to the point where we have, as best as we can achieve it, a politically neutral Public Service. Why is that important?
It is not just for those who are members of the Public Service and looking at this as kind of consumer protection legislation for the vast majority who do not wish to openly become candidates or go out and work in elections even though they may hold serious and considered views about the country and its affairs.
I am thinking now at the next step having gone from the individual public servant to the Public Service as a whole to the third dimension of this and that is the Canadian people.
I believe the Canadian people have the right to look to those who hold public office in this country with a sense that the affairs of our country are being conducted in a fashion that is fair, balanced and in accord with the public interest.
Party differences divide those of us who are elected to this Chamber. They ought not to divide those who work year in and year out in developing policy and furthering the implementation of government programs across this vast land of ours.
I know that it can be quite a chilling reality for many people to think that the civil servant with whom they would be dealing is someone who is actively affiliated with a certain particular political party, perhaps one that is opposed in interest to their own party. That is not something which represents an advance in the public policy of our country but a step backward.
With the historic perspective that I tried briefly to outline in the debate tonight, I hope that when we get to drawing the line that the hon. member wants to see in legislative form, which I agree should be there, we can indeed do it in a way that is fair and responsible for all concerned.
April 2, 1992

That includes the individual member of the public sector, the Public Service as a whole, the government that depends on the advice and the co-operative support of the Public Service, ultimately and above all the people of Canada who look to the Public Service for a fine tradition of maintaining good government and peace throughout our country.

Madam Speaker, it was very interesting to hear the comments of the member who spoke last on political rights for public servants. The history lesson was interesting, that back in the 1800s Public Service employees in many sectors were denied even the right to vote. As one of a category of Canadian citizens who were denied the right to vote well into the 20th century, perhaps I stand up to defend political rights with a little extra verve and commitment. We do have a democratic society. The right to participate in the political life of a democracy is the right of every Canadian citizen and one which should only be reduced or removed for the most serious of reasons in the public interest.
I was recently rereading a submission I made to the commission on electoral reform and I carry into this debate the principle that I put forward in that submission. The principle that should apply is that disenfranchising people should not be done and that if the commission had to err on the side of making it a little too easy for some people to vote, it should do that rather than err on the side of disenfranchising those who should not be disenfranchised.
I support the intention that I think the hon. member has in moving this motion, that the government bring forward legislation to clarify the political rights of Public Service employees. The problem is that the courts have already ruled quite clearly on this. What the government needs to do, first of all, is to repeal sections in the legislation that the courts have ruled violate the Charter
of Rights and Freedoms. The opinions of the government member who spoke on the motion may be of great interest, but they really are of no great moment when the court has already ruled on what is currently in the legislation. It has said that the legislation that is now in effect places unreasonable limits on democratic rights and that those limits are not justified in a democratic society.
The only provisions that the court left intact are ones that I think everybody would agree are basic and minimal restrictions on the democratic rights to participate in the political process. Those are the obligation on deputy ministers who advise on policy directly to government to refrain from political activity and the restriction that a Public Service employee who wishes to be a candidate has to have permission to do so and has to take a leave of absence while he or she does.
We have right now legislation that the courts have said is contrary to the Charter of Rights and Freedoms and after nine months the government has done nothing to make any efforts to change that legislation, to repeal the offending sections. I think that is the first step that has to be taken. In my view we then build on what restrictions need to be put in place that can be justified as absolutely essential to protecting the public interest, because that is the way our charter is framed. Any restrictions on freedoms have to be justified in the public interest.
We have been talking in committee for a month now about the kind of Public Service we want, the importance of a neutral Public Service, the importance of a Public Service based on merit. Quite shockingly to me the government has brought forward legislation that says merit no longer means that we want the best qualified people working in the Public Service of Canada.
There has been deep concern expressed to us from a number of fronts that what that is going to mean is the ability to politicize the Public Service again. We have to remember that legislation to establish the merit principle in the Public Service, to keep it politically neutral, was brought in in 1919 as the result of a whole history in the Public Service of appointments based on who your friends were and whether they got elected and whether they liked the candidate you worked for at election time. Yes, there was substantial pressure on Public Service employees to work for candidates at election time because otherwise they would not be in the Public Service after the election if a candidate won for whom they had not worked.
April 2, 1992

Certainly we do not want to go back to that. Yet there are many ways to undermine that. The current bill, Bill C-26, that the government has before a legislative committee is probably more dangerous to a politically neutral Public Service than is any exercise by a Public Service employee of a right to have a lawn sign or to make a contribution to a political party, or to make a few phone calls on behalf of a candidate.
The Prime Minister in the 1984 election promised that this was something that could probably be corrected quite easily by setting up a standing committee and bringing in new legislation that took many of the restrictions off Public Service employees in their right to be involved politically. The government never did that, and in fact when my predecessor in Ottawa West brought forward a bill to reduce the limits on Public Service employees' political rights, he eventually felt morally compelled to withdraw that bill because his own government insisted on tightening the screws again and again to the point where close to 50 per cent of Public Service employees were again fully denied any political rights of any moment.
This is an important principle in the bill before us. It is not one, frankly, that I expect this government to act on. But I ask it to consider seriously, since it is now into an era of regulatory review, whether its particular commitment to limiting the rights of public servants makes any sense. I ask it to consider, if it has any true commitment to the concept of building trust and partnership between the government and its employees, whether it does not think that most public servants can be trusted to exercise discretion and not to indulge in political activity that is in conflict with their public responsibility.
I frankly believe that most of them are mature individuals who value their jobs and who value their commitment to serve the public impartially. I think they value it more than the government does, and I do not think they are going to jeopardize their ability to serve the public or the future of their employment with the Public Service by acting foolishly in a political way. If we believe they
Private Members' Business
are the kind of individuals who cannot be trusted then I do not know how we can proceed with reform of the Public Service where trusting one another is really the foundation of revitalizing the Public Service.
It appears to me that there are in place mechanisms to deal with Public Service employees who do violate the trust placed in them by the public and by the government. Departments have codes of ethics. There is the obligation to act in good faith toward one's employer. We have conflict of interest guidelines for employees in the Public Service to ensure that their private activities are not in conflict with their public duties.
On top of all of that, do we truly need legislation? I doubt it very much.
We are dealing with the most fundamental right a citizen has in a democracy. That is the right to participate in the political process, to express their views on issues, to support the candidate of their choice, to support the political philosophy of their choice. Only for the most serious of reasons should we deny that right to 500,000 Canadians. That is how many people we are talking about.
The courts have said that the legislation which was in place is not valid; it has quashed those sections of the legislation.
I call upon the government to bring forward an amendment to repeal legislation that no longer has any force and effect and to make it clear to Public Service employees what their rights are.
